Elections are calls to order.
If the Europeans want more Europe, it is to build a societal project and not just to adopt even more technical directives.
Internal market regulation is indeed necessary, but it is far from being the entirety of the matter.
The 2009 program, like its predecessors, will miss the point.
Citizens do not expect the commission to merely complete or even simplify legislation.
await the commission to rise to the task assigned to it by the treaties, the locomotive, the idea box of the Union.
It is not enough for its president to be wise and silent, standing at attention behind the Council President.
We expect the Commission to act as a key player in reflecting on the nature of the societal project we need.
But what is the social project outlined in this program?
The 2009 program does not contain any major errors, but it is not the program our fellow citizens need.
Mr. President, it will be up to the new college to assume its responsibilities.
I only hope that he will be less deaf to the calls of the people than the current one.
Thank you, Mr. President. Firstly, a question to the council.

I believe that the financial and economic situation is much more serious than we acknowledge.

This is truly, for me, the collapse of the current system, a completely obsolete system, the system that has led to bankruptcy, that has led to land being completely exploited and choked by greenhouse gas emissions, that has caused underdevelopment in the Global South and that has caused urban decay in our cities.
I thank the President and the Commissioner. The current financial crisis clearly demonstrates that when the problem is global, a global response is required.
And this is particularly true in the field of agriculture or in the food sector.
This is why we have notably created the World Trade Organization, which we all agree on, and which seeks to establish globalized rules.

It turns out that it does not quite work as we would like, because we are faced with a problem that is as follows. We need to reconcile two things: the free trade that is necessary and which everyone agrees on, but also the equally necessary protections.
And the protection of national economies or agricultures does not equate to protectionism.
to achieve this, the approach we have taken for 60 years, originating from GÃ¢t, is an imbalanced strategy that involves reducing tariffs with the goal of ultimately eliminating them.
it turns out that, technically, the reduction of customs duties
It is difficult. The proof lies in a whole series of mathematical formulas: the South Korean formula, the European formula, or the most well-known formula, the Swiss formula.
It doesn't work properly because the product is not unitary.
It is composed of numerous elements with very different rules of origin, and technically reducing customs duties is not as simple as one might think.
We find ourselves in a technical impasse and are attempting, through political negotiations, to find a way out of this deadlock.

It turns out that, technologically, scientists have invented a new customs technology: deductible customs duty technology, which can be deducted by the exporter from the economy of the importing state.
In practice, this deductive customs duty is transformed into a customs credit equal to the amount of customs duty borne by the exporter in the importing country.
This customs credit has three characteristics: it is reimbursable, negotiable, and eligible for bonuses.
It is reimbursable when the exporter makes a purchase from the importer; he can deduct the customs duty he has incurred.
It is negotiable because if the exporting company that has paid the customs duties has nothing to purchase from the importer, it negotiates its customs credit on the stock market or with a bank.
And it can be supplemented if we want to help developing countries; the importer can offer an amount of customs credit greater than the amount of customs duties.
Well, with this technique, we create an international trading currency whose monetary mass is equal to the amount of existing customs duties.
For example, the European Union would offer 13 billion euros of international currency in the trade sector.
Mr. President, the Russo-Georgian conflict and the financial crisis provided an opportunity for the European Union to assert itself on the global stage as a full-fledged and leading political actor.
Thanks to your determination, Mr. President of the Council, Europe has succeeded in uniting and finding coordinated, effective, and rapid responses.
In the face of crises, Europe proves its existence and demonstrates its added value.
In the matter of immigration, for example, the every-man-for-himself approach was no longer appropriate.
The adoption by the European Council of the Pact on Immigration and Asylum, initiated by the French Presidency, represents a significant step forward.
In the fight against climate change, Europe must set itself concrete objectives and show the way to its global partners.

You have already expressed yourself on this matter, Mr. President of the Council, but we wish for this agreement to be as balanced as possible, as it must take into account the economic situation of our countries, which is currently almost destabilized.
but also to ask ourselves the question of the type of development we will choose for the future.
To rise to the challenges ahead, the European Union needs the Lisbon Treaty more than ever.
We understand the concerns of our Irish friends, but the status quo is not an option.
Ireland must present us with a solution at the December European Council. Many of us are demanding it.
In recent weeks, we have proudly observed a strong political Europe, united in adversity, standing firm in the face of its partners, and being listened to on the international stage.
We hope that this new European mindset will become the norm and endure.
The Lisbon Treaty is the best solution we have to achieve this. Thank you.
Madam President, Mr. Minister, I was present here when President Sarkozy came to negotiate the peace plan, and of course, I pay tribute to him for acting swiftly to end this war.
But this war is somewhat our failure. For fourteen years, we were timid. We silently witnessed the escalation of provocations in the separatist regions.

And this war, indeed, has awakened Europe by placing it before its responsibilities. But the fire continues to smoulder in the Caucasus, and we must do everything in our power to definitively resolve the frozen conflicts for the security of all Europe.
I am also aware of the divisions, Mr. Minister of European Countries, regarding Georgia's entry into NATO. Personally, I am against it.
I will make a proposal. I will ask the European Union to propose the status of neutrality for these Caucasian countries.
Only the status of neutrality will be able to ease tensions with Russia and definitively prevent this sub-region from new conflicts.
This status will ensure the security of these young democracies and contribute to our own security.

Over the last three days, the European Development Days were held, where the food crisis severely affecting the poorest countries was extensively discussed. The commissioner and Mr. the Minister both participated.
interventions have all emphasized the absolute necessity for developing countries to develop their own agriculture by optimally utilizing their land and natural resources.

in passing, the lyrical flights of those who called yesterday and still today for the reduction of state intervention, for cuts in public spending, for across-the-board liberalization, for privatization, for the relegation of agriculture to the sidelines as if it were a mere
This about-face, favoring massive public investment in agricultural production and food sovereignty, was at once comical and scandalous.
The future of agriculture in developing countries is directly related to the debate we are having today.

Alas, I do not feel that this health check of the CAP, initiated before the peak of the food riots and the disastrous market turmoil, takes into account the situation of the peasantry in the Global South and fully addresses the serious ecological, social, economic, and financial risks that we face today.

I therefore deeply regret that the strong relationship between Northern and Southern agriculture is so little addressed in both the Commission's proposals and the Parliament's report. The questioning of the promised billions of euros shows how much progress still needs to be made.
Mr. President, the report we are to vote on tomorrow represents the culmination of a year's work and negotiation dedicated to the future of the Common Agricultural Policy and our farmers.
Indeed, it was last November that Mrs. Fisherball came to present her proposals regarding the health assessment.

The Agriculture Committee of the European Parliament remained firm in the face of the Commission's initial proposals, which we deemed far too liberal.
I will remain vigilant with regard to the dairy sector and in particular the measures preceding the abolition of quotas.
I am particularly thinking of mountain milk producers, who must not become the poor relations of this reform. Care must be taken not to overlook them, as they will need more support than others.
I do not wish to play the role of Cassandra, but how can one envision the French dairy industry consolidated within a single region?
It is therefore with kindness that I welcome the proposal to establish a milk fund and the one to assess, as early as 2010, the increase in milk quotas according to market developments.

The calculation of the progressive modulation carried out by the Agriculture Committee seems fair to me and would allow us to strengthen the development of territories, rural areas, and sustainably preserve biodiversity.
I also commend the clarification of eco-conditionality, whose implementation had been a real headache for farmers until now.

I also hope that we maintain the tobacco fund amount that allows us to keep our small holdings in Europe, as well as a significant workforce in a region where nothing else can be exploited, and which enables us to avoid imported products.
Finally, Mr. Minister, we have greatly appreciated your commitment throughout these negotiations.
You have demonstrated a great deal of patience and determination, and you have not spared any time, far from it.
It is a true pleasure to work with you by your side.
your collaboration with us was highly effective.

Agriculture is indeed an economic sector that cannot respond solely to market signals.
Its activity has impacts, of course, on food self-sufficiency, but also, too often, on territories and employment.
The removal of market instruments would inflict a severe cost on our agriculture.
Decoupling, for example, presents a real challenge for certain territories with suckler cow and sheep farming, and I am pleased to have heard Mrs. Fischbo speak on this issue earlier.
Moreover, it is clear that strictly adhering to historical references would impose a significant constraint on any possibility of reform.

However, I still believe that the issue of the second pillar of the CAP (Common Agricultural Policy) is essential, as rural areas need to rely on agricultural activity to develop employment in the countryside.
so we need to think about this problem of the second foot without, of course, amputating the first.
Given that Minister Joillet is about to leave us, I believe this Parliament should thank him.

Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, our group enthusiastically supports the Small Business Act project presented to us by the Commission last June.

Certainly, as early as the 2000s, initiatives were launched targeting SMEs, and I particularly think of the excellent work of our colleague Dominique Glasto on the SME charter. These initiatives were appreciated but deemed insufficient as they often remained in the realm of good intentions.
Today, we must go further.
The severe economic crisis that our countries are going through, with consequences that are particularly worrying for SMEs, prompts us to do so if there were any doubt.
In this regard, the Small Business Act represents a new and decidedly proactive approach.
In a few weeks, we will be examining Mrs Erog's report on the Commission communication, but today, through the submission of this oral question, we have sought to call on the Council.
Sir, we have noted with interest the conclusions adopted yesterday by the Competitiveness Council and would like to know if the European Council of December 11th and 12th next,

Ensure its conclusions are well-founded and provide a strong impetus for the rapid transposition of the overarching guiding principle of S Small First into the regulatory frameworks of the Member States.
We hope that the Council will commit to the principle of the action plan, which is annexed with a view to concrete measures.
In this regard and within the brief time allotted to me, I will emphasize three areas in which we need compelling impetus.
Impact assessments, which should be systematic, and regular monitoring with oversight by the European Parliament of the implementation status of the Small Business Act in the Member States.
Access to the public market.
The code of good conduct has no binding effect. Together, we need to be more imaginative and inventive, and propose concrete, tailored measures that genuinely open up these markets to SMEs.
Finally, access to financing is more essential than ever in the current context.
Your proposals are good, Minister, they must also include support for the supply.
There is an urgent need.
Thank you for assuring us of the Council's willingness.

Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Commissioner, we all know that SMEs are the backbone of the European Union, as they employ more than seventy percent of the Union's workforce and account for ninety-eight percent of European businesses.

But, as has already been stated, these millions of small and medium-sized enterprises are now being affected and threatened by the financial crisis because it is eroding purchasing power and household confidence, impacting order books.

It is therefore the cash flow of SMEs that is at risk, and it is necessary, consequently, to ensure support for their activities by making sure that banks guarantee effective access to the financing needed for the continuity of their operations.
The entire focus is on the conclusions of the Competitiveness Council on December 1st, as discussed by the Minister, and the recovery plan approved by the European finance ministers.
Making the needs of SMEs a permanent political priority for the Union is essential, and I would like to commend the action plan in support of the Small Business Act for Europe.
It indeed translates the will to ensure the effective application of the guiding principle, to give priority to the smallest first, that is to say, European SMEs.
However, as the Commissioner stated and as we all say, the Council must genuinely engage with the other institutions.
European. For this principle to now become effective, it is necessary to go beyond the declaration, to move towards implementation in all European policies and programs.
However, we can say that this action plan is a genuine response to the urgency of the situation.
I would like to commend, Mr. Minister, the determination of the French Presidency of the Union, which has enabled the rapid translation of intentions into actions.

all childcare time is counted as working time.

Mr. President, it was a very fine French presidency.

On the energy-climate package, Europe is taking a first step, and in this regard, this first step is immense.

The current crises demonstrate that the Union now more than ever needs the best institutional tools to be effective.

President Sarkozy raised the issue of reducing certain VAT rates, and I fully share his perspective.

The challenges facing Europeans provide an opportunity for the Union to reveal itself to them as more united, more responsive, and more concerned with their protection.

We must thank the French Presidency. We are well aware that it is not entirely unrelated. Thank you, Mr. President.
The situation in Gaza is known to everyone.
What we are discussing here in Parliament is natural.

But we are calling on the Security Council to take a stand. We are asking that the bodies take a stand, that the European Union take a stand, and we, in Parliament, discuss and do not want to take a stand.

I believe that, given the urgency of the situation in Gaza, it is of the utmost importance for this Parliament to take a stance and clearly state its position on how to halt the massacres currently taking place in the Middle East.
I find it unacceptable that this Parliament does not have the courage and clarity to vote on a resolution following our debate.
That is why our group is requesting a revision of the Conference of Presidents' decision and to conclude the debate that we must have.
Let us address the situation in Gaza through a resolution that will demonstrate this Parliament's clear and firm position, by a majority, to stop the massacres in Gaza.

We want a resolution, and we must be aware that we have a political responsibility regarding what is happening. This political responsibility cannot merely be a discussion; it must be a resolution that clearly states what we stand for and what we condemn.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, now more than ever, the draft directive that Parliament is about to vote on evokes in me a very mixed feeling.
It is true that Rapporteur Klins has carried out a long-term, laborious task for years and has negotiated with talent, especially during the trilogue.

It is also true that the directive includes a number of significant advancements towards improving the functioning of the internal market and the collective management of financial assets, which have been welcomed by the European investment fund industry.

It remains that the debates and discussions in the Council and Parliament were never entirely free, as the outcome was known in advance. For some stakeholders, it was imperative to introduce the European passport for management companies at all costs.
In principle, there is little to criticize about the passport; it is entirely defensible. However, it is necessary to ensure the introduction of the passport for management companies.
It is accompanied by the necessary guarantees, particularly in terms of fund oversight, as it leads to a separation of functions across borders.
Now, I regretfully note that the system in place is not only complex but is also subject to divergent interpretations.
It risks encountering practical difficulties very quickly, which will harm the European industry, from funding to exports, particularly exports to third countries.
I have duly noted that my position is in the minority. Nevertheless, I do not feel uncomfortable.
In normal times, I would have been tempted to say that this practice will allow for definitive conclusions to be drawn on the matter and thus to determine.
who is right between those who trust in the adaptive capacities of market players and those who adhere to a more cautious approach.
It is not excluded that success may be at the end, but, on the other hand, nothing guarantees it either.
However, very recent events, notably the Madoff scandal and its implications for the financial asset management industry, are not reassuring.
Scepticism gives way to my anxiety.
The investment fund industry will not be spared by the financial crisis, as we are already witnessing.
Fundamental reevaluations may be necessary in this crisis context.
In these contexts of deep crisis, making choices that either dilute the responsibilities of the actors or assume perfect cooperation between regulatory authorities can indeed seem incongruous.
I tell you, as I believe, this directive was also one from a bygone era before the crisis.
She is marked by a certain nonchalance.
Indeed, the financial system is facing a lasting and fundamental crisis of confidence. Entire sectors of its architecture must be rethought.

We must not forget the primary function of OPCM (Mutual Funds) and investor protection, through risk diversification and the establishment of strict rules. By voting for this text as it stands, without fully understanding the implications, we are essentially acting as if nothing, absolutely nothing, has changed.
This autism bodes nothing good. That is why I am abstaining, even though I have signed the compromise amendments negotiated with the Council.
The circumstances, the improvements made, seem to me of little weight compared to the principles I have just explained.

Mr. President, although the regulation on animal reporting has been in force since January 2007, it appears that Member States are not systematically complying by providing annual reports as requested.
Thus, a comprehensive analysis remains random as many elements are lacking regarding the resources deployed to conduct inspections.
As a member of an animal protection association and part of an animal defense collective, this topic concerns me greatly.
Associations have been fighting desperately for decades, and it was only in 2007 that guidelines were finally established in this area, revealing a certain laxity among member states.
I would even venture to say a certain amount of bad will, for after all, we know that the implementation of control and inspection measures is by no means insurmountable.
We are aware of the slaughterhouse locations, we know the breeding sites, we are familiar with the livestock transit routes. So, where lies the issue?

I believe it is important in our time, when public opinion is increasingly and rightly sensitive to animal welfare, whether in terms of breeding, slaughter, or transport conditions, that states respect these sentiments.
Since I have the floor, I would like to add regarding transportation that it would be indispensable to consider, independently of travel times, the local climatic conditions.
Indeed, a several-hour journey in the Netherlands in the spring is hardly comparable to the same journey time in midsummer in a country like Greece.
Shouldn't night-time transportation be mandated in these latter cases?
I thank you for considering this proposal in the future.

Mr. President, I am delighted that it is our British colleague, Paris, who has tabled this text, which goes to show that the Roman soldiers, two thousand years ago, were right to go to Britain and bring with them olives and wine.
But then, consequences will have to be drawn from it.

It is not very reasonable, symbolically, to locate the food agency in Helsinki, and it is not reasonable for the European Commission not to reverse course on the following points: first, restoring aid for almond growers, and second, halting

The attacks against olive trees, particularly in Andoussie and across Europe, must cease. We need to halt the attacks on red coral fishermen in the Mediterranean and the assaults on European vineyards through uprooting.
I am dear to our commissioner, our president, Mr. Barroso, to organize a grand banquet in Portugal with ewe's cheese and wine.
Mr. President, indeed we have all advocated for the closure of Guantanamo, and we have all applauded President Obama's decision to shut down this prison of shame.
Today, the question of accepting the detainees from Guantanamo should not be one that we have to consider.
As Europeans, remaining faithful to our values of upholding human rights, we must take responsibility, as it is our duty to welcome these former detainees.
And we have read, and here I am addressing the Council, we have read in the press that some Member States were not very enthusiastic about this reception.
I would like to make a sincere appeal to the Council and in particular to the reluctant Member States to agree to receive these female prisoners on their territory.

I will tell you, dear colleagues, that the worst-case scenario would be that the strong argument for aid generated by the closure of Guantanamo is lost because we did not step up when Europe was called upon.

This is important because the European animal feed sector is one of the most significant sectors in agriculture, both in terms of production, as it accounts for half of agricultural production in the European Union, 120 million tonnes, and in terms of turnover, approximately 50 billion euros.
The European Union indeed counts 5 million breeders and 60 million households owning pets.
In the past, the European Union has had to deal with several health crises, which means that today, we must be more vigilant about transparency to meet the expectations of both farmers and consumers.

The provisions outlined in this report have the advantage of incurring minimal costs for industries while providing significant benefits to consumers, who are increasingly attentive to the quality of the products they purchase.
Adopting this report will help mitigate risks by ensuring improved product quality, enhanced control, better traceability, and comprehensive information for breeders, and ultimately for consumers.
Today, with the increase in international trade, it is more than imperative to strengthen all preventive measures to ensure that the food crises we have experienced in the past do not recur.

This report succeeds in balancing the right to information while strictly defining the nutritional elements that must mandatorily appear on labels, and the right to intellectual property, which is crucial for preserving the competitiveness of our industries.

I believe that indeed, manufacturers should be required to immediately notify the use of any new raw materials included in animal feed formulations to ensure transparency and facilitate monitoring by the competent authorities.
Including an emergency procedure that allows for the addition of a new dangerous substance to the list of prohibited materials seems to me to be absolutely essential.

Similarly, giving breeders the possibility to consult the competent national authority or the European Commission in case of doubt about an unfair allegation allows for better verification of systems to protect the customer while preserving the fairness of commercial transactions.

I would like to offer my full support to this excellent report, as experience has shown that regulation of pet food labeling, prioritizing quality, transparency, traceability, and control, is the best way to prevent further crises in Europe.

Ladies and Gentlemen, it is certainly not Europe, nor its High Representative for Foreign Policy, Javier Solana, former Secretary General of NATO, who can play the role of mediator between Israel and the Palestinians.
Are they all the more expected to fund the reconstruction of the Gaza Strip, as they are doing today for Kosovo, Lebanon, or Afghanistan?
Americans and Israelis bomb, Europeans fund the reconstruction.
Such is the distribution of the tasks entailed?
Now, it should be the vandals who pay.
Egypt is at the forefront of discussions on peace, focusing on a prolonged ceasefire with Hamas.

But the challenge to be met is formidable insofar as the new Israeli government, under pressure from the third man, Lieberman, leader of an extreme right wing that is democratically accepted there, risks having its task significantly complicated in these negotiations.
Indeed, Netanyahu, who is presented as the future Prime Minister, has always opposed a truce with Hamas.
Another difficulty is that the Palestinian Authority of Mahmoud Abbas has, in six years, become a sort of international protectorate whose legitimacy has greatly diminished among the population.

the final element that must be taken into account is the expansion of Israeli colonies, which has never ceased since nineteen hundred and sixty-seven, in the context of the creation of a Palestinian state in Jordan, a particularly delicate matter.
Today, the ball is in the Israeli court, but will the hawks on both sides accept this divine truce that both parties demand without having the means to achieve it?
Allow me to add a reflection on France's reintegration into the NATO integrated military structure, which will be up for debate with the Vatanen report.
This reintegration will impose severe obligations on France.
Indeed, we are reintegrating NATO even though the Cold War has been over since ninety.
Sarkozy seems to have forgotten the fall of the Berlin Wall and Russia's return to the ranks of free nations.
Should the logic of blocs be reinforced in an era of multipolarization and the rise of emerging countries, including in military terms?
Moreover, France's integrated structure vision will compel it to increase its contingent in Afghanistan, even though it already has 3,300 troops deployed on the ground.
With what budget will she finance this, given that her defense budget is set to fall below 2% of GDP and over 30 regiments are to be disbanded?
Paradoxically, we will increase our budget contribution to join NATO while simultaneously reducing our military presence in Africa.
European defense, dear to President Sarkozy, will thus be a pillar of the Atlantic Alliance.
One only needed to read the Treaty of Lisbon and its additional protocols to be convinced of this.
Whether in terms of foreign policy or common security, the European path is a dead end that will lead only to alignment with the Americans and their allies.
It is this logic of erasure that we reject in the name of national sovereignty and independence, resting in particular on our autonomous nuclear deterrent.
Madam President, I congratulate our three rapporteurs for this quite remarkable synthesis they have achieved of the current state of our common foreign and security policy.

Sir, as you know better than anyone, Europe is expected to take its place on the world stage today, a place assigned to it by its economic and demographic power and the richness of its democratic and humanist values.

It is a fact that, despite the regularly expressed desire of more than two-thirds of our European fellow citizens, as you have stated, certain progress has indeed been made, I grant you, over the past ten years. However, we are forced to acknowledge that this Europe still does not exist.
If a recent illustration were needed, his erasure in the resolution of the new drama in the Middle East would serve to demonstrate it.
There is always a need for a European presence in Gaza to play an active role in both aiding the survival of the population and the reconstruction of the territory.
countries and in the fight against arms smuggling, which had enabled this territory to be transformed into a launch base for requests of all kinds.
Despite the fine words uttered at Charmilchi and Jerusalem, nothing has yet been done in this regard.

I hereby renew a question already posed during the Lebanese crisis. When, Mr. High Representative, can we hope for the deployment of a European fleet in the Mediterranean, as we had done to counter piracy?
We have the means to do so.
Will we ever have the will to do so.
Mr. Commissioner, Mr. President, dear colleagues, the Parliament's decision to accept the urgency requested by the Council for development.
The handling of this file was unanimous, both in the Fisheries Committee last week and this morning in the plenary session here.
Indeed, we are all aware of the necessity for the European Union to uphold the commitments made in Marrakech last November by the competent international commission, the CICCTA.
Concretely, this is about implementing the recommendations adopted by this organization to curb the persistent phenomenon of overfishing of red tuna in the
Atlantic East and the Mediterranean and to address the serious dangers that arise for the future of the species and thus for the fishery itself.
Two of our colleagues, the Committee on Fisheries, Mrs Fraga and Mr Rovaroued, were present in Marrakech and will be speaking on this subject as part of this debate.
I would like, for my part, to reiterate the importance our Commission attaches to this file, which involves the main dimensions of the common fisheries policy, namely, management.
the resource, fleet management, adherence to international, regional, and bilateral agreements, technical measures, and above all, control, which I will revisit later.
This distinctive file thus serves as a test, in our view, of the credibility of this common fisheries policy.
For this reason, it was obviously out of the question for the implementation of the new recovery plan to proceed without consultation with the European Parliament.
I am therefore pleased that the Commission has ultimately chosen the only legally and politically acceptable path for implementation.
recommendations of the city, namely a formal regulation proposal based on Article thirty-seven of the treaty.

The transposition into EU law of commitments made by the Commission on behalf of the European Union in regional fisheries organizations is indeed not a trivial matter, and we insist that it always take place under the democratic scrutiny of our institution.

At the core, I welcome the various proposed measures, which, although restrictive for our operators, are commensurate with the challenges at hand. I emphasize that the most significant of these measures...
The most important of these measures are undoubtedly those related to, and will continue to relate to, control, as it is truly the case that without control, no reconstitution plan can be effective.

However, my group remains extremely critical of this proposal because it risks turning against those we intend to support.
In seeking to reduce the burdens on businesses, we risk depriving them of the conditions of transparency and trust indispensable to their management and the dynamism of their activities.
Firstly, I believe it is necessary to be clear about the thresholds and what is meant by microentity.
These are small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) with more than ten employees and a turnover of over one million euros.
Regardless of the member state, this represents a very large majority of businesses.
Certainly, they may be local and have little presence in the community market. However, it remains that the need to present accounting rules will not be abolished for them.
Accounting rules will confront them every time they want to deal with a banking institution, partners, or sometimes negotiate with tax, economic, and social institutions.
At that point, accounting rules will be imposed on them, and they may have to pay more than for regular accounting in order to meet criteria that they may not necessarily control.
I do not see progress in imposing the accounting obligation outside of the four common standards of the European Union.
This is not merely a competition issue. It is quite simply a matter of economic integration and Community law, and of equal treatment for all businesses in the European Union.
In other words, clearly, simplifying accounting requirements for SMEs is a necessity.
Three initiatives, indeed, point in this direction, whether it be the proposal we are discussing today, or the international framework IF.
LRS, whether it is the revision of the fourth and seventh accounting directives for which the European Commission should soon make proposals to us.
These proposals were promised to us by 2010, it seems they have been extended, but I do not believe that this deadline extension is sufficient reason for this.
to rush and do a half-hearted job, as these three proposals, while sharing the same objective, may not have the same structure. It seems to me, Commissioner, that it would be better to...

is clearer for businesses to provide them with a single, comprehensive solution that will enable them to reconcile the goal of simplifying obligations, desired by all, with the practical reality of small businesses that need it.
The current issue is that the European Commission is delaying the proposal to revise these directives, which is hindering our discussions.

I therefore call on the European Commission to expedite the dialogue on the issue of exemption, which today divides both European institutions and economic circles, and to conduct an impact assessment.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, and dear colleagues, as my colleague Elisabeth Morin-Chartier and others have indicated, on February 27th and 28th, the violent storm Cynthia hit several French regions, causing fifty-three fatalities and extensive material damage.
The storm was of rare intensity, causing devastating floods along the French coast.
After Maire, Europe is once again affected.
Brittany, the region of my colleague and friend Alain Cadec, has been severely affected.
Three French departments have been declared in a state of natural disaster: Brittany, Poitou-Charentes, and Pays de la Loire.
In the face of these disasters, the European Union must demonstrate its responsiveness and express its solidarity.
It is not just through words and a resolution, but above all through financial assistance that we can support the victims of these disasters.

I therefore invite, and my colleague Christophe Bechus joins me in this initiative, the European Commission to rapidly unlock the European Solidarity Fund to aid the affected regions in dealing with the damage.
This catastrophe demonstrates the relevance of Michel Barnier's proposal to create a European civil intervention force.

Europeans must act together because disasters are increasing and affecting our European territories, particularly our most isolated and vulnerable regions, such as the islands in the Indian Ocean and the Caribbean.

Madam President, I too would like to congratulate our rapporteur, JÃ¶rg Leirid, on his text and his cooperative spirit in this matter. I particularly support his proposals on the financing of air safety, since we are talking here about air safety and not air security.
For many years, our Commission has been fighting to have the principle accepted that stricter safety measures should be borne by the Member States, and I fully support our rapporteur on this point.
Indeed, security does not only concern travelers, but all citizens, and it is the responsibility of states to take measures to combat terrorism.
It is therefore unjustified for air passengers alone to bear the burden of financing security measures in airports and on board aircraft.
And this is all the more true given that, in transport modes such as rail and maritime, states fund, depending on the case, either partially or fully, security measures.
I therefore believe that we must stand firm before the Council and defend amendment thirty-two of the report adopted by our Transport Committee to the very end.
I had another point to briefly address.

While I support the progress on non-discrimination and transparency that the text will bring, I do not believe that the purpose of this directive is to establish a single, identical European system for safety fees.
While enforcing adherence to common rules, it is necessary to allow Member States to retain their current system of fee collection.

In this way, in countries like Spain, Italy, or France, royalties are voted on by Parliament, and in such cases, it should be the authority responsible for challenging laws that serves as the independent supervisory authority.
This is the purpose of Amendment 40, which I hope many of you will support when we vote on it.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, the report I am presenting to Parliament attempts to explain that, in the fight against climate change, agriculture has a place and a role to play.
Nature reminds us this week that volcanoes, in particular, can have a major impact on human activities and the climate.
But this requires, nonetheless, that men and Europe, in particular, take responsibility to combat what is known as climate change.

My report attempts to demonstrate that agriculture can simultaneously continue to reduce its carbon emissions, decrease its consumption of fossil energies, and above all, achieve another key objective.
On the one hand, it actively participates in carbon sequestration to globally reduce carbon emissions and increase the amount of carbon captured and sequestered.
This report attempts to demonstrate that in agriculture, we should move away from a compartmentalized approach, whereby every time we face a problem, we create a new directive.
on the soils, in the water, in pesticides, who knows what else, and attempting to tackle the agricultural issue with the ambition to address it comprehensively, in a systemic way, and
In this approach, we need to identify ways to ensure that agriculture, as I mentioned earlier, not only reduces its energy consumption but also actively contributes to carbon sequestration.

In particular, it is the role related to photosynthesis, biomass, and above all, what is close to my heart, also linked to the soil's ability to sequester organic carbon, a capacity that European soils possess.

I believe that this approach, which I am introducing in this report and which I hope will be adopted during the vote in the plenary session in Brussels, will enable European agriculture to enter a phase of sustainability and ensure:

ecological transition to this agriculture that would put it ahead of a number of other continents or other forms of agriculture, ensuring that it can be economically efficient, ecologically sound, and I believe also, from that point onwards, socially beneficial.

This report addresses a specific issue: the fight against climate change and agriculture. However, it aims, I hope at least, to open up other perspectives to feed, in particular, the debate that will take place on the future of agricultural policy after 2013.
I am addressing the Commission, and I will also address the Agricultural Committee, as I have often done in the past. Additionally, I will approach the various ministers when the opportunity arises.
I believe we need to take a turn.
This 2013 pact must be ambitious.
It is essential that it be based on objectives that enable citizens to understand why we need a common agricultural policy.
We need a common agricultural policy because agricultural Europe must ensure both food security and commit to sustainability.
In any case, this is what I propose in this report, and I hope that the Parliament, by a large majority, will follow me on this.

Mr. President, I would like to emphasize first and foremost that the precautionary principle implemented by most European governments by closing their airspace in a targeted and temporary manner was a wise and prudent decision.

The safety of our fellow citizens must take precedence over any other consideration, and under these circumstances, the attitude of certain airlines demanding the immediate and full reopening of airspace based on one or two test flights is, at the very least, indecent.

I believe it was Mr. HeÃ©ain earlier who spoke about the complementarity of transport modes, particularly with the train, and I will take this opportunity to express how much I regret the paralysis of air transport.
has been exacerbated in certain countries like France by the disruption of rail transport due to strikes in these irresponsible and incomprehensible circumstances.
Returning to our subject, I would like to commend the Commission's decision to authorize the granting of state aid to airlines affected by the ongoing disruptions.
This is a decision of common sense in a context already marked by crisis, but its aids must be of an exceptional nature.

In this regard, I hope that among the criteria considered for their allocation will be the exemplary behavior demonstrated by companies in the compensation awarded to their clients who were victims of flight cancellations.
Indeed, it is unacceptable for certain companies to abuse the force majeure clause to evade their obligation to compensate passengers under Regulation 261/2004.
Travelers are victims of the current situation and, if no alternative solution is offered to them, they should not, in addition, bear the financial cost.
Moreover, travel agencies are exempt from the obligation to reimburse travelers for unused flights.
And this, too, is not normal.

Companies such as travel agencies have insurance policies that cover them in exceptional circumstances, like the situation we have been experiencing for the past few days, and it is therefore essential to ensure that travelers are adequately compensated for the flights that have been canceled.
Mr. President, oars, chaos, paralysis, cacophony, catastrophes, disasters, monuments believe in the press to evoke the closure of European airspace and its consequences.
I will not linger on what has already been mentioned, particularly regarding the immense, one might say abyssal, financial impact of this crisis, whether direct or indirect.

And while I welcome the possibility of considering the provision of exceptional public aid to the aviation sector, which has already been severely tested since September 11, 2001, I remain perplexed by Europe's management of these events.

Knowing that 750 European passengers have been affected, many of whom remain stranded across the globe. Given that the economic losses are exponential with each passing day, how can it be explained that it took so long?

It is not one, two, three, or four, but five days for the European transport ministers to meet via teleconference to coordinate their actions and decide on the creation of differentiated traffic zones.
Secondly, no one disputes the necessity of applying the precautionary principle as an absolute priority, but today, as we are gradually reauthorizing traffic in certain areas,
With the weather conditions remaining unchanged and the volcano still active, one is entitled to wonder what additional safety guarantees for passengers we could have provided more swiftly.
Thirdly, an adaptive action model has been developed, based on the principle that volcanic activity can change in nature, which will continue to conduct updated assessments of corridor safety.
Must these test flights be carried out by civil aviation and airlines?

Finally, if this persists, worsens, or recurs (which is probable), the established management model should provide for greater coordination among member states and special operational procedures based on real data, as well as improvements in...

coordination of other transport means in exceptional circumstances, but also take into consideration the necessary coordination of assistance for the repatriation of the tens of thousands of stranded passengers, who also have the right to information and support.
So far, only isolated and national initiatives have been taken. Madame Delvo, who is speaking?

containing chemical substances in aerosols and strengthening the control of the presence of chemical substances within the European Union, and finally, the development of guidelines for a common definition of disability that can include people suffering from chronic diseases or cancer.

Madam President, the oil rig leak in the Gulf of Mexico is an outright ecological and economic catastrophe.
It would appear that irregularities have been identified in the granting by the United States Department of the Interior of forest permits.

elected representative of the European Union's outermost regions and the OCTs, which are almost entirely composed of islands, numbering close to 130.
distributed across the three continents, I must express here my great concern for our islands regarding offshore oil exploration projects.

the President, Mr. Commissioner, this is an extremely important matter regarding consumer protection.
A recent survey indicates that the food security situation has deteriorated in the eyes of Europeans over the past ten years, and one in three consumers remains skeptical about product quality.
Updating, simplifying, and clarifying food labeling in the European Union is an obligation for better consumer protection.
Allow me to address two points.
Regarding the color-coding, we are in favor of this color system provided it is accompanied by a reference to the nutritional values expressed as percentages.
And then I am opposed to a mandatory nutritional labeling requirement for wines and spirits.
We advocate for the development of a regulation specific to wines and spirits within the next three years, rather than the five years proposed by the European Commission.
This is what I wished to point out, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner.
Mr. President, Madam High Representative, this attack on a civilian vessel by Israeli commandos clearly demands an impartial and credible investigation.
But what credibility can we attribute to a commission that would be both judge and party?
This attack took place in international waters, and thus concerns the international community, particularly the European countries bordering the Mediterranean.
Europe should make its voice heard more loudly and become more actively involved in the search for a political solution based on two states, each with Jerusalem as its capital.

Europe is making significant financial efforts to contribute to the development of Palestinian territories, but unfortunately, it is largely absent from the political process that should lead to the creation of a Palestinian state.
The financial and budgetary goodwill we demonstrate is not enough.
We must also express political will and take the necessary steps to make our voices heard.
the brutal attack on the Mavi Marmara by the Israeli army elicits emotions and condemnation
Emotion in the face of the nine victims of the civilian assault, condemnation as this reasoning in international waters constitutes a violation of international law.

By doing so, the government of Israel is penalizing its own people, for ultimately, we see that with the strengthening of extremisms, the ultimate goal of security in the region is moving further out of reach.
Yes, now more than ever, the government of Israel must abandon the policy of force.
I would like to point out, however, that the extensive media coverage of the Mavi Marmara flotilla, orchestrated from Turkey, casts doubt on the exclusively humanitarian purpose of this operation.
An investigation appears indispensable to shed light on the assault, but also on the preparations that preceded this expedition.
I hope that the government of Israel will agree to a substantial international participation in this inquiry to finally restore the paths of justice in this region.
Madam President, Madam High Representative, I congratulate you on the new momentum generated by the launch of the partnership for modernization and its pragmatism.
This new partnership, if nothing else, would at least have the merit of underscoring the extent to which Russia is an indispensable geopolitical partner for the European Union.
I also commend the positive remarks on cooperation with Russia in crisis management.
A few remarks, however.

While the demands of the Union are always prioritized, the interests or positions of its partner are systematically undervalued or disregarded, whether in the field of energy or in how it may analyze the Eastern Partnership and the Atlanticist aspirations of its closest neighbors.

I also note that the firmness demonstrated by most member states and the European Union in their discourse, the virulence of their condemnations of human rights violations, seems to be directed solely at Russia.

The rhetoric is more cautious, the diplomacy more nuanced, as is the case with China, for example, regarding these systematic violations of the rule of law. Not to mention the Laogai, this global factory that disregards minimal European social standards, while our French or European workers are unemployed.

I would remind you of the adage of Augusta, father Augusta, towards the peaks by the narrow paths, for this is how I view the efforts of today's Russia, freed from the criminal Marxist poison that, for so many decades, bled and imprisoned this country.
The current Russian Confederation has managed to lift the spirits of an entire nation, despite the significant difficulties and setbacks it still faces.

So a little modesty, Gentlemen Europeanists, especially when the super European state itself achieves none of its fine objectives despite increasingly costly means and the progressive domination of the states of Western Europe and Central and Eastern Europe.
I cannot help but recall that this assembly showed more indulgence towards the Soviet Union, which was more communist, than towards Russia.

They are, moreover, often the same ones who, yesterday, advocated for the unilateral disarmament of the West and participation in Mikhail Gorbachev's common house, who now feel the most virtuous indignation and the greatest prudery towards the Russia-EU partnership.

On this matter, I must inform you, in case you are not already aware, of new historical phases that will emerge due to the progressive translation of the Soviet secret archives. Mr. Pavel Stroilov has managed to obtain these archives, which have already revealed and will continue to unveil much information.

Unpleasant surprises and the classic example of groupthink regarding the reality of the end of the Cold War, which was really about M. Gorbachev and the betrayal of today's Europeanist powers, who at the time, with enthusiasm, sought to make certain Soviet projects possible.
At the risk of repeating myself, Russia is an essential and strategic partner for the European states, and our relations must be strengthened to the benefit of all parties.
This country is far closer to us in terms of culture, civilization, history, geography, mutual interests, and shared risks than some of the states you are about to admit to the European Union.
Chair of the Council, it is often said that necessity makes law.
In the face of the crisis, an evident truth emerges: a necessity that has become unavoidable, the need to innovate and be creative.

In this regard, I welcome the step taken by the Council, a step that I hope will ultimately be a giant leap, leading us towards genuine economic governance, because let us not be mistaken, mere coordination of economic policies will remain inadequate.
May we achieve a true budgetary federation, not forced by circumstances, but because we ourselves have decided it.
let us return to the council's decision, which nonetheless pleases me.
Strengthening the preventive aspect of the Stability and Growth Pact is a positive step, but there can be no true budgetary discipline without sanctions for those who fail to comply.
They have been strengthened, but not yet specified, which is a regret.

Otherwise, I will express my satisfaction, among other things, regarding the decided orientations, such as the famous competitiveness assessment dashboard, because it is indeed about regaining competitiveness and sustainable growth for all.
Greetings once again on the project to introduce a bank tax, the acceptance of a financial transactions tax, and the acceleration of financial regulations reform.
Mr. President of the Council, all these decisions and orientations seemed, just a few months ago, or even a few weeks ago, unrealistic, illusory, and indeed hypothetical.
You are correct, it is true, it is a profound cultural shift on the scale of European small-step politics.
However, that being said, it is now mandatory for states to implement these guidelines very concretely in October.

It now depends on the Council whether the step taken will be a historic giant leap or merely a pious hope, something we will all bitterly regret, and in particular, the majority of citizens who will have to endure its consequences in their daily lives.

Mr. President, we have already discussed this at the Conference of Presidents. Many groups are divided on this galloping report, and visibly, the Parliament, all the groups, still need to discuss because there are problems, contradictory points that the groups have not been able to resolve.
That is why we were requesting that the debate and vote on the Gallop report be postponed until September 2, when the Conference of Presidents is to be held.

Madam President, I must admit that I struggle to follow my colleagues who are so keen to flex their muscles and claim an exclusive hold on our legitimacy in comparison to the other institutions of the Union.
Unfortunately, their posture is often derisory.
But, when the members of this household, through hard work and conviction, assert a well-argued position,
We defend what resembles a European common interest against rigid states, the situation changes completely.
In this debate on European supervision, the Parliament has played that role.
Regarding the European Systemic Risk Board, for which I am the shadow rapporteur for my group, I advocated, like the rapporteur, Ms. Goulard, for an ambitious approach.
I have put in place mechanisms to ensure a certain level of efficiency, and I have emphasized the paramount importance of the European Central Bank.
Why?
Because the European Central Bank is indeed the only Community institution in this group and because it has demonstrated its seriousness.
Out of Christian charity, I shall refrain from mentioning the names of all the institutions and those great figures who suddenly vanished during the storm.
We can consider ourselves fortunate to have had at least one captain on board at the height of the crisis.
I would therefore be reassured to see tomorrow's macroprudential supervision backed by a strong community institution, while microprudential supervision will inevitably remain fragmented.
In certain disturbed scenarios, the European Systemic Risk Board must begin its work as soon as possible.
The future will reveal whether adjustments are necessary, but it is crucial to start from a sound foundation as systemic risks impact the entire European and global banking sector.
Mr. President, the final agreement reached on the overhaul of the directives relating to industrial emissions is more than acceptable, and I commend the compromise work that has been done.

This final package incorporates the key points of amendment that I advocated for with several of my colleagues within the Environment Committee, aiming to make this text a bold yet realistic legislation.
Firstly, maintaining a degree of flexibility for businesses and competent authorities in granting exemptions.
Next, I would like to acknowledge the new version of OSN, which has been so controversial and which, no longer limited to certain sectors, now seems much more feasible.

It is also important to emphasize that the agreement reached allows for better alignment with the ETS Directive and permanently removes the somewhat irrelevant idea of creating a SO2 and NOX quota market from the text of the new directive.
A few caveats to bear in mind, however, and more specifically the provisions relating to the ground.
The SOL directive still being pending, this important issue will unfortunately only be addressed by those Member States that have their own specific legislation.
Tomorrow, Parliament must adopt the elements of the agreement reached following the trilogues.

Enormous efforts have been made from all sides to avoid sending this text to conciliation, a text which I must remind you, is of crucial importance for both industry and European environmental policy.

My group and I share these concerns.
