Last year, at this very time, we were already busy in this very hemicycle, urging Europe to do everything in its power to reach an ambitious and binding agreement in Copenhagen.
We have seen that the result did not meet our expectations and ambitions.
So the concerns a year later are the same, if not even more acute.

In order to constrain or convince our partners today, we must demonstrate that our resolve is absolutely intact, showing, for instance, that we are given the means to honor our commitments to the countries of the South.
For this, the implementation of innovative financing mechanisms, and I heard yesterday President Sarkozy's speech at the UN, is becoming a necessary evidence.
For example, the introduction of a carbon tax at our borders is not to be excluded.

It would act as an incentive mechanism for countries that are not going far enough in their climate commitments, and much more than a threat ultimately, and a way to protect our jobs and businesses, especially to better address the pre-crisis.

Madam President, in my view, the need to revalue family leave is not approved. Increasing the minimum threshold for maternity leave is a step forward, a benefit, and we should not be entirely demagogic in comparing the economic impact to the qualitative benefits that are difficult to quantify.

But the problem is essentially twofold: firstly, the economic context, which is true, but not sufficient to continue neglecting millions of families for decades. Secondly, the legal gaps in the report, as the text includes several types of family leave whose legal bases are not reconcilable.
Let's consider the adoption leave included in the text on the same footing as maternity and paternity leave.
Personally, as an adoptive mother and for all those I represent, I appreciate the willingness to grant rights equivalent to those of biological parents.
In fact, I am the small additional package that Mrs. Morin added to the EtrÃ©LA report.

If the goal is to improve the health and rights of all women in the labor market, adopting women, having become mothers just like others, are entitled to the same rights and the same workplace protections.
They are mothers like any others, fully entitled to adopt a child whether it is over or under twelve months old. Moreover, there is no discrimination, please note, as stated in the text.
As for adoption, I regret that the text was not more thoroughly explored.
It was not even informed by the Rambo impact study.
All of this is not well developed, which is clearly a weak point.

Nevertheless, despite these reservations, I will support Mrs Estrella's report because, beyond economic considerations, there are men and women who must not only better fulfill their parental responsibilities in a society that

Increasingly resigned when it comes to the education of these young people, but moreover, because it is our duty to ensure that no one has to choose between sacrificing their children for their work or sacrificing their work for their children.
Finally, we do not sit on the Council but in Parliament. If we directly elected members are not ambitious, tell me who will be.
Madam President, Commissioner, Mr. President of the Council, I would like to intervene and not revisit the debate as it has unfolded so far.
We discussed a 2011 budget within the constraints we know, namely those of a deep crisis that Europe is going through, with national public deficits, which can lead to two hypotheses.
These national public deficits constrain the European deficit, or these deficits at the national level must provide a new direction and a fresh impetus at the European scale.
That is the question.
I ask you, Commissioner, above all to try to think, when we discuss a budget revision, when we start talking about budget prospects for the period after 2013, not to
Remaining completely immersed in the context of the crisis, unless I am to say and to tell all European citizens that, resolutely, Europe will remain in crisis for a long time.
Our entire problem is indeed managing the crisis and reducing our deficits and debt, but it is also about preparing for the post-crisis period.
And this is where the budget question arises.

We will only be able to emerge from the crisis, as Joseph Dale immediately pointed out, if the European budget, precisely because it is European, can provide us with the means to regain what is currently lacking in terms of growth, job creation, innovation, and research.

This is the crux of the matter, and it is for this reason that we must discuss the budget, rather than constantly incorporating, as we all too often do, the issue of the crisis and the issue of deficits. In this regard, the Council is excellent.

I have noted that in Adouville, Angela Merkel and Nicolas Sarkozy even announced in advance a treaty reform, without even discussing with Mr. Van Rompuy at all, to penalize all states that would not respect budgetary discipline tomorrow.

This is where we stand at the Council level today, as Parliament is asking for one thing, and in particular from the Commission, it is to try to advance the European project, and this happens through the budget.
So you have noted a number of things on which we are in complete agreement.
There is a need for more stability.
Obviously, we need to collectively find a way to have a much more flexible budget, as these are necessities and the reactivity of Europe is at stake.
It is also, of course, a matter of setting priorities and organizing the effectiveness of the European budget.
We will all agree on this, all agree, it is a necessity.
But where we must be clear with each other, Mr. Commissioner, is that we need a timeline; we must set goals together. This cannot remain mere words, mere commitments.

Texts that are, incidentally, very interesting and with which I agree almost 100%. But now, we need to get down to the specifics, particularly on a crucial question that we have been circling around: own-resources.

How can we ensure that clean resources are available tomorrow for Europe, not just for Europe, but for all European citizens, and how can we collectively find a path to growth that is even stronger for Europe?
It is up to you, Sir.
Mr. President, I would like to focus my remarks on the preparation of the upcoming G20 summits.

Everything has been said by the previous speakers regarding European economic governance, the need to strengthen European economic governance, to reinforce the Stability and Growth Pact, and to better involve the European Parliament and, of course, also the national parliaments in the process.
I would like to briefly mention two challenges facing our nations, and indeed the members of the G20, which, in my view, must be addressed in the context of the upcoming G20 meetings.
The challenge of the currency war is that of the volatility of raw material prices.
I believe that, regarding these two issues which are genuine threats to global growth and which cause significant imbalances on our planet, the European Union must take action.

European manages to organize itself, to adopt common positions, and to equip itself with the means to speak with one voice at the upcoming G20 summits, but also at those that follow, and more broadly, on the world stage. Thank you.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, I would first like to congratulate our colleague Diogo Feyo on the quality of the report and the ambitious proposals it contains.
This also demonstrates that the European Parliament is fully engaged in a debate that is crucial for Europe's future, and we can only welcome this.
Moreover, the Greek crisis served as a revealer of the dysfunctions undermining the economic governance of the European Union.
I note on this point Mr Feio's proposal to establish a permanent mechanism for financial stability.
We must also address the problem at its root.
For this, I believe that the solution also lies in strengthening the Stability and Growth Pact, particularly with regard to sanctions.
This is essential if we want to achieve a sustainable improvement in the budget situation of the States, which is not always popular.
It is restrictive, but we have no choice.

Mr. President, I believe that the report clearly highlights the issues surrounding the marine environment in terms of fisheries, aquaculture, transport, tourism, energy, mineral and biological resources, research, combined with climate change.
This is a considerable development potential that should be secured, protected, and sustainably enhanced, as the future of humanity depends on it.
The report also rightly notes that the European Union is the world's leading maritime power and that these outermost regions provide it with the largest exclusive economic zone in the world.
In light of such a finding, it is therefore the responsibility of the European Union to implement an ambitious policy, a major maritime policy.
If it is not the world's leading naval power that does it, someone else will do it in its place.
However, it is noteworthy that the resolution does not go very far in this direction.
It is not with 50 million euros that one can claim to occupy a position of leadership in global politics.
Finally, while the outermost regions have a recognized strategic position, as they are present in all oceans, it would seem that
It was wise to give them a leading role in a grand ocean strategy, which, unfortunately, was not retained in the report, and I regret that. Thank you, Mr. President.
Commissioner, I would like to address the anti-counterfeiting agreement currently being negotiated, particularly with the United States.
This agreement also raises questions in the United States, particularly among officials at the U.S. Patent Office.
Moreover, seventy-five American law professors have just sent a letter to President Obama.
He deems that ACTA, this mere executive agreement, would be contrary to the American Constitution.
as the European Parliament is about to, as you know, adopt a resolution on the ACTA agreement, which continues to raise significant concerns and is far from achieving unanimous support.
Among our fellow citizens, I believe it would be useful to have a very clear response from our American interlocutors. On two points: can ACTA be ratified by the United States?
Is ACTA, in their eyes, a binding or voluntary agreement?
Indeed, an anti-counterfeiting agreement already absent of China, India, and Brazil, which would not be enforced by the United States, would significantly lose credibility.
I thank you.

Mr. President, throughout this difficult birth of the directive on alternative funds, I have consistently advocated for the principle of equal treatment between fund managers, whether they are from the European Union or not.
This principle may sound like an obvious truth, but its evidentiary nature has encountered countless challenges.
The result presented to us today is satisfactory in nature.
I would like to thank the negotiators, and especially our rapporteur, Mr GasÃ¨s, who, after this particularly painful birth, deserves a substantial period of maternity leave.
Above all, I would like to emphasize that the issue of third-country treatment must still be viewed from two perspectives, whether one is inside or outside the European Union.
Thanks in large part to the European Parliament, all funds sold in the European Union will effectively be subject to comparable regulation.
One can then speak of a more or less level playing field of love.

It remains that, during the transitional period, non-European Union entities will benefit from the national placement regime, while European Union funds and managers will be subject to the directive, which is generally stricter.

The situation is different in markets located outside the European Union. In these markets, European funds and their managers will remain subject to the directive, which is not the case for third-country funds.
It would then be much more difficult to sell European products in the rest of the world, as they will be less flexible and more costly.
We must be aware of this disadvantage, even if it was partly inevitable.

As for the depositaries, bearing in mind that this will also make the task more demanding, particularly due to the new responsibilities incumbent upon them, the increase in costs should lead to substantial changes in the profession.

Mr. President, I am not saying this to express my opposition, but to point out that this new regulation is not trivial. Its implementation, though necessary, will also present challenges of which we must be aware.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, especially at the beginning of the 21st century, patients need appropriate information to be fully involved in their care journey, knowing where to seek care, deciding on the best treatment in agreement with healthcare professionals, and strictly adhering to the planned treatment.
Today, patients demand independent, comparative information tailored to individual needs.
Unfortunately, the proposals for revising the directive transmitted by the European Commission did not adequately address the needs expressed by European citizens.
These proposals opened the door to direct promotion by pharmaceutical companies, which we consider to be a nonsensical approach in terms of addressing the actual needs of patients.
This operation holds no interest for either citizens or member states.
It signified, on the contrary, additional bureaucracy, increased expenses, and putting patients at risk.
It is for these reasons that we initially submitted a revised proposal for these texts, thereby requesting the Commission to review its draft.
This approach, also adopted by my colleague Carl Schulter from the Greens group, enabled our rapporteur, Mr Fechner, whom I welcome, to undertake a significant revision of the Commission's proposals.

In parallel, we had tabled around sixty amendments aimed at further protecting the health of our citizens and facilitating patients' access to independent, comparative information tailored to individual needs.

The adoption of these amendments in the environmental committee has enabled a greater emphasis on patients' right to information, rather than making the provision of information an option for pharmaceutical industries.
In light of the compromise amendments secured, we have resolved to withdraw our position of rejection, as the substance of the text has evolved in a positive direction over the past few months.
The draft report, as amended, has succeeded in counterbalancing the initial proposals of the European Commission.

However, we will continue to refuse to allow healthcare professionals to be instrumentalized for distributing brochures and information provided by pharmaceutical companies to their patients without any oversight from health authorities.
Similarly, we will oppose the authorization of industrial and informational campaigns, particularly regarding vaccination.
Information cannot freely flow from pharmaceutical firms.

Experience shows that we need to be very vigilant, and indeed, to conclude, what happened with the Mediator drugs illustrates the extent to which we must be vigilant and ensure that this balance point, as we have sought it with this draft report, is achieved.

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, Madam Minister, unity and realism will, at least I hope, be reflected in the vote tomorrow on our resolution for this 16th Conference of the Parties on climate change.

I hope that our commissioner in charge will be able to promote the pragmatic objectives that we must collectively achieve, but also to uphold the indispensable conditions set by Europe that are associated with them.
In these negotiations, we must also not lose sight of the legitimate expectations of fairness from our fellow citizens and industries.
It is the world that must fight climate change, not Europe alone.
Thus, recognizing the importance of intellectual property that is far too little protected will be essential.
Green technologies should benefit the greatest number, but we must not, for all that, sell off our present and future knowledge, nor compromise our indispensable struggle against climate change.

Similarly, requesting common methods for calculating emissions, as well as the verification and publication of data, so that all industries and sectors are held to the same standard, seems like a most legitimate request and not a negotiating tactic.
Finally, and this is more contentious, as my colleague mentioned earlier, the shortcomings of the current clean development mechanism system will also need to be addressed.
Dear colleagues, we are all well aware, to our regret, that the true negotiating power is not held by the European Parliament.
But the willingness of many European MPs, including myself, to work and contribute to a positive outcome of this conference should be encouraged, not neglected, as we have felt in recent days.
If Europe aims to be strong within international dialogues, the same must be true for all these legislators.
Madam President, the European Union often presents economic partnership agreements as an opportunity for African countries.
Is she then despairing that these agreements are not being signed as soon as possible?
But the question that confronts us is why these countries are not rushing to sign agreements that are favorable to them.
Clearly, assessments diverge on the quality of these agreements, and as long as these differences in opinion persist, the ACP countries will be reluctant to sign them.
Would it not be appropriate to go further in dialogue and understanding by listening to the concerns and expectations of the ACP countries?
These actors wish to discuss development strategies, while Europe often responds solely with market opening.
It is this listening that the ACP-European Union Joint Parliamentary Assembly imposes upon itself.
I believe that other European institutions should follow suit if we are to build a genuine strategic partnership between Africa and the European Union.
Mr. President, Christians are undoubtedly one of the most persecuted religious groups in the world.

In the Middle East, they are perceived by certain extremist groups as, and I quote, "legitimate targets," with the goal being their complete departure from the region. This is the very region where Christianity was born, and their historical presence is essential to a certain balance.
The events at the Baghdad cathedral are merely the culmination of a situation we have passively observed for far too long.
The European Union, as a global actor and trading partner of many countries in this region, must strongly express its indignation in light of the situation.
Any and all forms of discrimination are intolerable.
Democracy will only triumph in this region when the most fundamental human rights, such as religious freedom, are respected.
Colleagues, we are all confronted with the serious crisis currently unfolding in CÃ´te d'Ivoire.

It is evident that the decision of this country's Constitutional Council to challenge, in violation of the electoral code, the results of the elections officially proclaimed by the Independent Electoral Commission, is unanimously condemned by the international community.

The European Union, the UN, the African Union, the Paritary Parliamentary Assembly of the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) Group of States, the KoAS, and soon, undoubtedly, the European Parliament, are calling for the respect of the official proclamation of the...

election results and the inauguration of the new President of the Republic, as recognized by the Independent Electoral Commission. The Independent Electoral Commission, I should add, is a body validated by the United Nations.
All political groups in the European Parliament have expressed, in a joint statement, their agreement on these essential points.

They also called for a halt to any escalation of tension in the country that could lead to civil war, which would be for CÃ´te d'Ivoire a human, social, and economic disaster, something that must obviously be avoided at all costs.

Madam President, I in turn would like to thank our four rapporteurs who have done remarkable work and have significantly enhanced the value of the European Parliament's contribution to the text initially proposed by the Commission.
The citizen initiative we are about to vote on in the EPP with enthusiasm is a major advancement of the Lisbon Treaty.
Let us not be mistaken, this instrument can truly transform the European political landscape, provided it is used with both responsibility and boldness. I emphasize, responsibility and boldness.
It can help bring European citizens directly into the European political debate.

It can contribute to the emergence of a European public opinion, that is, men and women who are citizens of Europe, debating together, taking positions together, and rallying around truly European issues.
But let us not disappoint our fellow citizens.
Let us urge our member states to swiftly adopt the implementing measures where necessary. Let us not disappoint our fellow citizens; the strengthening of European democracy is at stake.
Mr. President, I in turn, like several of our colleagues, wished to address the issue of the persecution of Christians around the world, particularly the Christians of the East.
There is no need to recall the horrible acts recently perpetrated.

I would like to emphatically reiterate that defending Christians in the East, as well as everywhere else in the world, advocating for religious freedom, and promoting diversity of beliefs are causes that should unite us.

Beliefs are about advocating for freedom, democracy, and human rights, which are values at the heart of the European project and which are, of course, in any case, we are all convinced of this here, universal values.
It is truly time now, beyond indignation, emotion, and solemn condemnations, obviously, it is truly time now to move from words to action.
I urgently call on the authorities of the European Union, the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, as well as all our leaders, the Ministers for Foreign Affairs.
Implement precise measures to establish a clear and concrete action plan to prioritize respect for religious diversity and the fight against all forms of religious persecution. Thank you.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, Madam High Representative, we all agree that the situation in the Sahel region has significantly deteriorated.
And allowing a lawless zone to establish itself at Europe's doorstep is a danger we must firmly and promptly combat.
Extremist groups are proliferating and threatening the lives of civilian populations.
In my turn, I deplore the loss of life and the hostage-takings, and I am concerned for the European citizens on the ground.
Until now, Morocco has been a bulwark against all kinds of trafficking from the Sahel.
Henceforth, drug, arms, or human traffickers are circumventing Morocco by transiting through Mauritania to the Canary Islands en route to the European Union.
It is, I believe, the responsibility of the European Union to act in order to help these states put an end to these threats.
Europe's security is at stake not only on our territory but also in its immediate neighborhood.
It is time for us to act, and I call on the Commission and the Council to implement an action plan to assist in the return to security in the Sahel.
It was stated, but I associate myself with the expressions of sympathy and support that have already been voiced towards the Tunisian and Egyptian peoples.
He represents a symbol of hope for all defenders of freedom.
A thought also for the victims.

I would now like to state that the European Union, which, as has been mentioned, has been criticized for its lack of response, must firmly stand alongside the Tunisian and Egyptian people to help them successfully open their countries to reform and establish democracy.

The European Union has decided to support Tunisian leaders in initiating a peaceful transition, preparing the organization of upcoming elections to achieve freedom and enable the Tunisian people to attain prosperity, development, and social peace, along with an economy that will provide employment opportunities for youth.

I would say in conclusion that the Union for the Mediterranean faces a significant challenge because the Jasmine Revolution has triggered a wave across all the states of the Maghreb, the Near East, and the Middle East.
She must implement a robust strategy towards these countries.

But beware, in the face of this legitimate democratic movement, Europe must find a balance between non-interference in internal affairs, support for the legitimate aspirations of the people, and stability.
Commissioner, my colleagues have repeatedly emphasized this point.

At a time when Europe is questioning itself about a common strategy for its raw material supply, and especially rare earths, we cannot neglect the immense potential represented by the intelligent valorization of our waste.

Strengthening European standards to improve the functioning of collection chains, addressing issues of leakage or illegal export of waste, and increasing our collection targets must be at the core of this legislation.
Let us not forget the main actor in the success or failure of this regulation, the consumer.
Citizen empowerment is crucial if we are to implement effective legislation.
And to achieve this, my dear Carolines, the eco-contribution, among other systems, has proven to be one of the most relevant tools.

Producers of electrical and electronic equipment must, of course, become more involved in the collection and recycling system, but we cannot absolve citizens of responsibility for the waste they generate.
Our citizens must be actors, not spectators, of European environmental policy.

Madam President, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I would also like to begin by echoing the remark just made by Mrs. McGuinness regarding the essential link between the food issue and the agricultural question.
The issue that concerns us is the rise in food prices and the consequences this can have for a number of populations around the world, but also in Europe.
I would first like to try to share an observation.

The tendency towards increasing agricultural prices and agricultural raw material costs is, for me, a long-term trend that will persist for three key reasons: the world's demographic evolution and the resulting increase in demand, the shift in dietary habits, and the growing constraints on agricultural production.

the global population. Second, the fact that with climate change, we have entered a phase of climate variability that poses problems, whether it be drought or flooding. The third point, because the world is also developing.
With new emerging countries, consumption levels are rising.
The tension in agricultural markets and agricultural commodity markets is a significant and persistent trend.
It is exacerbated by price volatility, and price volatility is a consequence of the financialization of the global economy.
It is on this very subject that we must also focus if we are to resolve both the agricultural and food issues.

To achieve this, what the Commissioner said is important. There are two key elements: yes, there needs to be transparency regarding stocks, but there also needs to be a public policy on stocks in Europe and stock management on a global scale, particularly at the level of the UN.

Second point, there needs to be regulation of financial markets and financial speculation, particularly by preventing the speculative volume from becoming completely disconnected from the physical quantities traded on the markets.
We cannot accept that, on the issue of food, speculators come to speculate without considering the consequences this may have, as it concerns the food of the world and humanity. I conclude by saying
This leads me to two major consequences: we need a strong European policy, and we strategically reaffirm Europe's commitment to being a global player in food and agriculture.

Secondly, we need to change our development policy to ensure that, on a global scale and with Europe as an actor, we reinvest in agriculture, as we will need all forms of agriculture to feed the world.
Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, as in 2008, the price of agricultural raw materials is advancing in global markets?
We are only at three percent of the 2008 level.
the decline in production in certain traditional export zones due to climate change, the diversion of cereals for agrofuel production, and speculation.
The financial factors that amplify upward pressure are responsible for this situation, as demonstrated in reports by the IMF, the French authorities, and also stated by the Commission.
The consequences of this new food crisis are severely affecting the 1.2 billion people worldwide who live on less than $1 per day.
Since the month of October, an additional forty-four million people have joined those living below the poverty line.
With two days until the G20 meeting, what is Europe waiting for to take measures similar to those approved in the United States?
Since January 13, 2011, the U.S. administration has required the limitation and transparency of financial funds' positions on agricultural commodity markets.
This is the first step to counter the speculators' appetites.
The impact is dramatic for European breeders as well.
They are no longer able to feed their animals.
Hundreds of farms are in bankruptcy.
Five years ago, wheat was worth 100 euros per ton. Today, it is trading at nearly 300 euros.
The rules of the game have thus changed completely.
The Commission demands that farmers adapt to market signals. It would be well advised today to follow its own advice.
Faced with this crisis, the European Union cannot afford to wait until thirty-two thousand fourteen to find solutions.
We must confront the crisis, and I propose three concrete actions.
Firstly, the creation of cereal stocks in producing countries to make them available to breeders at subsidized prices immediately.
Secondly, indexing the prices of meat paid to breeders on the changing cost of animal feed.
Thirdly, for 2011, a mechanism to transfer a portion of the aids intended to support cereals to animal productions. Thank you.
Mr. President, are we prepared in Europe to face a pandemic?
The answer is yes, but there is a but.
The 2009-2010 H1N1 flu episode revealed that each Member State reacted on its own, with little coherence or even solidarity.

As a fictitious rapporteur on this file, I believe it was necessary to make these observations but above all to go further, to be constructive and concrete for our citizens, it must be said, and this is indeed what seems most regrettable; they have likely lost a bit of confidence in public health messages.

The report by Mrs Rivasi, which will be voted on tomorrow, takes into account her fundamental priorities, which include, among others, the systematic strengthening of cooperation between Member States and improved coordination with the...

European health institutions, a clarification of the roles of European structures for managing health risks, an assessment of the vaccination and communication strategies implemented in the Member States.
This is therefore a good report. I congratulate the rapporteur. It is still obviously essential that it not remain a dead letter.
It is the responsibility of our member states, which retain most of the competences in this area. It is, therefore, a genuine responsibility towards our citizens.
Mr. President, it is my turn to express my profound emotion following the cowardly assassination in March of the Pakistani Minister responsible for Christian minorities, Mr. BatÃ¢ti.
This terrorist assassination follows numerous others targeting courageous, tolerant Pakistanis, lovers of human rights, defenders of human rights and women's rights, I must say.

Once again, we urgently call on the Pakistani government to shed full light on this cowardly assassination and to effectively, truly effectively, ensure the protection of those threatened by fanatical religious extremists.
I am thinking, of course, primarily but not exclusively, of Ms. Chery Raymond.
I wished to also, once again, vigorously call upon all relevant institutions of the European Union to include in the negotiations towards
prepare future cooperation agreements, including the cooperation agreement between the European Union and Pakistan, with a clause upholding religious freedom and human rights.
Mr. President, for the record, with the crisis and the explosion of the real estate and credit bubble, the Irish state had to intervene to support the banks.

The Irish public deficit, the cumulative budgetary balance of central and local governments and notably social security, is estimated at thirty-two percent of gross domestic product in two thousand and ten.

If the Irish government, which is struggling to refinance itself through the markets, wishes to access loans from the mechanism and the European Financial Stability Fund, it will have to meet social and fiscal reform obligations, even though these areas fall under subsidiarity.
In our view, this is not contradictory.
As a physician, I would say that in the case of fever, it is futile to blindly prescribe antipyretics without attempting to treat the underlying cause.
In the event of the allocation of these funds, it is incumbent upon this state to undertake a financial cleanup in order to address its excessive deficit and rectify its previous errors.
This austerity plan is expected to increase GDP by ten percent over the next four years.

Just as a bank, without interfering in an individual's private life and management, would condition a personal loan on a guarantee of solvency, so too can the European Union lend to Ireland based on consolidated solvency.
without interfering in his private management, the bank will encourage the individual to negotiate, for example, a salary increase or to borrow elsewhere.

By respecting subsidiarity, the European Union, based on a memorandum established with the IMF, considers that this solvency requires a reduction in the legal minimum wage and an adjustment to pensions, without exempting itself from fiscal measures.
It is up to Ireland to decide whether or not to implement these measures.

This is not an open door to European Union interference in areas of subsidiarity, which could dangerously impose a European minimum wage level, but rather a protection of the Eurozone's stability through a process of mutual guarantee.

Of course, it is appropriate to assist Ireland, as well as other countries in distress, which also protects us, but not at any cost, especially not at the cost of seeing a state unable to repay its debts in the long term, thereby jeopardizing its own citizens and those of the entire European Union.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, the eruption of the Icelandic volcano last April, and many of us have said so just now, provided a painful illustration of the fragmentation and inefficiency of European airspace.
Each one of us, in this assembly, has been directly affected.
five million of our fellow citizens found themselves stranded without any real alternative transportation solutions.
And one year after this exceptional event, new European measures are still awaited.

A first crisis exercise, as you mentioned, Commissioner, related to volcanic ash is indeed scheduled for April 13 and 14, under the coordination of Eurocontrol of the ICAO and DIATA, but it is crucial that the ESA takes on a genuine leadership role for the coordination of safety measures at the European level.
It is certain that the information provided by the London and Toulouse waves needs to be refined using more modern technological means.

These data, as seen last April, can however be contradictory and may lead each Member State to make decisions regarding the closure of their airspace that are less driven by information than by emotion.
In this context, the role of the ESA is crucial in providing a harmonized interpretation of this data, as well as ensuring the centralization and proper dissemination of information.
Beyond the information provided by the VACs, AISAA must establish a mechanism for collecting available data by closely involving Member States, airlines, and their pilots.
This centralization of information and coordination of all relevant stakeholders will prevent the chaos and inconsistencies we witnessed last year.
I therefore expect the Commission, together with the ESA, to rapidly submit concrete proposals that will fully contribute to the implementation of the European Single Sky.
Dear colleagues, this tax is important.
This is not a revolution. One cannot say that everything was wrong before and that everything is perfect now.
However, it does present a number of significant advancements at this provisional stage of our work.

The main issues, in my opinion, concern better regulation of distance selling and, in particular, online sales. This is addressed in Chapter 3, as consumer rights in this area need to be strengthened.
E-commerce is highly beneficial; it expands consumer choice, enables them to secure the lowest prices, and also provides small and medium-sized enterprises and artisans with new market opportunities.
To make progress in this area, it was necessary to do so in a truly European way, that is, on a few very specific points, to establish a complete harmonization of rights and obligations for all.

In very practical terms, it was necessary for an Italian customer buying on a Belgian website or a German website to know that, from now on, they will benefit from the same rights and the same protection.
This is what this directive will make possible.
This means that its cooling-off period will be extended to fourteen days across the entire Union.
This means that he immediately knows the total amount he will have to pay, without fear of any unpleasant surprises afterwards.
This means that, thanks to the double-click, he will correctly verify his order.
Obviously, all of this will disrupt certain habits.
In many respects, there are nuances in national law of which each person is convinced are fundamental, even though sometimes one cannot even find a trace of them in neighboring countries.
But living together in Europe means learning to adjust one's habits somewhat in the service of the common and general interest.
Let's be clear, this text will need further improvement, and we will have to do so in the coming weeks with the Council and the Commission.
I appreciated the initiatives that have just been taken in this regard.
But we have already accomplished substantial work, thanks to our rapporteur, AndrÃ© Ashchoab, whom I warmly thank.
But the true fruit of this labor is above all the fact that the amendments will be voted on tomorrow by all the political groups.
Consumer confidence in the European Union's internal market is very fragile.
It was necessary to have this political unanimity to preserve it and to hope to strengthen it.
At point number seven, after the first paragraph, a first bullet point should ensure respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, in particular:
freedom of speech and assembly, and the right to peaceful protest, as well as the right to listen to and address the legitimate demands of protesters, and to ensure their safety.
Madam President, dear colleagues, Mr. Commissioner, the agreement reached between Europe and the United States is a step forward, but it is only a stage that places Europe before a dilemma.
The transport committee and the Commission itself have highlighted this.
Either we accept an agreement that disadvantages European businesses, or we suspend the agreement and risk losing the benefits gained since 2008.

Allow me, then, to draw a parallel with the licenses of private and professional pilots, a text that will be discussed before the summer, as the pilots among whom I count myself find themselves faced with a dilemma.
the European Aviation Safety Agency, seeking to harmonize licenses across European territory, will do so to the detriment of the eighty to ninety thousand general aviation pilots.
Directly affected, some holding only a single American license, and to the detriment of, importantly, businesses and jobs associated with this activity.
I would like to draw your attention to this project, which has no security foundation.
There are thirty-one fewer accidents among American license holders.

The objectives of the basic regulation text 216 provide for the recognition and equivalence of licenses, the benefits of which are not seen in waiting for hypothetical agreements postponed until 2014.

Therefore, I suggest a very open-sky agreement and even invite you to accompany me when I occasionally come to Parliament, piloting the aircraft myself, to demonstrate that an American pilot's license is perfectly safe.
Madam President, at this stage of our debate, I will inevitably be led to repeat or to endorse some of the points that have already been made.
But I also wanted to say that, like many of my colleagues, the problems we are facing, which the entire European Union is currently facing, cannot be resolved by any single Member State alone.
No member state should face the challenges ahead alone, which, once again, in my view, concern the entire European Union.
I am thus truly calling for the European Union's ability to organize itself and respond in a joint, solidarity-based manner.
I believe that the time has truly come now to lay the foundations for a genuine European policy on immigration and asylum.
Over a year ago, a European pact on asylum and migration was adopted.
The time has come now, I believe, to outline this in a very concrete manner.
We have indeed, Madam Commissioner, we have heard a number of recommendations that she made.
I would like to revisit this and strongly emphasize certain proposals.
Yes, at all costs, the resources of the Frontex agency must be strengthened.

Yes, we must forge closer cooperative relations with the states on the southern shore of the Mediterranean, accompany them, of course, assist them, and identify appropriate tools.
The Commissioner, I believe she went to Tunisia to discuss mobility partnerships.
Yes, we must strengthen these instruments with a sense of responsibility, with a spirit of solidarity, but also with a clear and practical mindset.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, you are undoubtedly aware that the most intense discussions we have had here regarding your communication have centered on the role of public services, services of general interest, within the single market and their legislative implementation.

communication that does not meet the expectations and needs of stakeholders, users, and all stakeholders, public services, and that also does not align with the objectives you otherwise formulate.

The Lisbon Treaty provides us with the legal framework for this.
you must now translate them into legislative proposals.

Mr. President, firstly, congratulations to all the rapporteurs for their gigantic work on the occasion of these responsibilities, and I also welcome the presence of the Council for this debate.
The seat of the European Parliament in Strasbourg is a matter of European identity and it is not solely an economic issue.

I am discussing this today in this chamber on the occasion of the debate on the 2009 discharge, because the symbol of Franco-German reconciliation is being treated by some members of the Committee on Budgetary Control as a mere means of making savings.
The issue of Parliament's expenditures also interests me.
In this regard, I suggest holding the group weeks in Strasbourg rather than Brussels. This would allow us to make better use of our Parliament seat in Strasbourg.
since we want to save money, I propose other measures, for instance, eliminating the Friday afternoon off for our colleagues, as well as removing the additional days off for journalists.
Europe is sufficiently attractive that one is not obliged to bribe journalists.

Let us not hide behind the budget argument to appropriate an important issue that goes beyond the scope of budget control, even though I welcome the important work of Ville, our rapporteur, on this discharge.
Finally, since we are discussing economics, I also hope to see the moralization and improvement of the compensation system for sponsored visitor groups.

I do not find it very ethical, and it gives a very poor image of our institution, that the group leader is reimbursed in cash, in specie on the day of the visit, without any work or control of what the group has spent.
Sometimes, as I indicate to you, the allocated sum exceeds the amount of actual expenses.

It would be logical for groups to send an estimate in advance to the visits service, to receive Parliament's support for expenses, which would be paid into a bank account, and for the balance to be paid upon presentation of the invoices actually paid, with a ceiling, of course. Thank you.
Madam President, I am addressing the Commission and my colleagues, and I acknowledge the presence of the Council.
The question that arises today stems from the management of the Schengen area in 2011.

This is no longer the space of the five member states of the 1980s; on the contrary, it is an area that has continually expanded in recent years and now includes twenty-five states, three of which are non-members of the European Union.
Like all European policies, Schengen cooperation must therefore adapt to the reality it now covers, which is no longer the same as it was ten years ago.

It is in this light that we must read the proposals of the Italian and French governments and the pragmatic and necessary responses provided today by the Commission in its communication on immigration.
Mutual trust among the States party to the Schengen Area is indeed the cornerstone of Schengen cooperation.
But this trust is based on mutual obligations.
If one of the parties fails to meet its obligations and creates air pockets, the entire system becomes defective.
It should therefore be possible for other States to address this failure by re-establishing temporary and strictly regulated control of these borders.
In doing so, these failing states will be clearly encouraged to better secure their external borders.

Furthermore, as presented by the Commission, these measures would fully respect the Schengen acquis, insofar as these controls would be reintroduced as a last resort and the decision would be taken at the European level, rather than intergovernmentally.
Such measures will be intrinsically linked to the full range of long-term measures envisioned with a view to a common migration policy.
It is particularly essential to strengthen Frontex, to provide for greater solidarity. I will conclude by supporting the states located at the external borders.
The situation that the Mediterranean has experienced in recent years merely highlights a gap in the Schengen area.
In two minutes, Madam President, within a few weeks, migrants from Mediterranean rim countries have accounted for a significant percentage of France's annual immigration.
This achievement is not static but must, on the contrary, evolve.
I hope that this proposal is swiftly adopted to ensure better management of our Schengen area and, in doing so, secure our common external borders. Thank you.
Mr. President, the European Union has finally imposed sanctions on Syria.
But unfortunately, she seems to be doing so with a trembling hand, carefully avoiding any direct criticism of the Syrian regime's leadership.
This lack of determination and clarity is obviously interpreted by the protesters as a form of abandonment and by the authorities as indulgence, allowing them to intensify.
suppress a repression so cruel that one cannot imagine for a moment that at the same time Syria could be elected to serve on the Human Rights Council, of the organization of the
The United Nations, while today, the Syrian authorities are denying UN observers access to the city of Era, which has been the scene of terrible violence against defenseless civilians.

Syria's presence on the Human Rights Council would be an insult to the victims and their families, an encouragement for this regime to use brutal force against its own people, in contempt of the very values that the Human Rights Council is supposed to uphold.
So, Madam High Representative, what diplomatic options are you considering to avert such a disaster?

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would first like to congratulate my colleague Carlos Colow, who has done the work of a goldsmith on this report, and as God knows, it was very complicated.
Bulgaria and Romania have made considerable efforts to strengthen the control of their borders and have succeeded in doing so.
Whether it concerns police and judicial cooperation, data protection, visa policy, or the control of air, sea, and land borders, the latest assessments are very clear.
All technical criteria are met.
We can only acknowledge this state of affairs.
Bulgaria and Romania are now technically and personnel-wise capable of implementing this Schengen acquis.
Moreover, while no obstacles currently hinder this expansion of the Schengen area, we note that a number of recommendations have been addressed to these two countries.

I hope that these recommendations will be rigorously followed, especially with regard to the borders between Bulgaria, Greece, and Turkey, as you know that the mutual trust between Schengen States is based on the full respect by these States of their reciprocal obligations.
If one of the parties fails to meet its obligations and creates air pockets, the entire system becomes defective.
I fervently hope that an agreement will be reached in the Council to welcome these two countries into the exclusive circles formed by the Schengen States.
We all in this hemicycle understand the impact of this type of decision on the citizens concerned.
Once again, congratulations to Mr. Coelho for his report. Mr. President.
Mr. President, in its Europe 2020 strategy, the European Union has set itself the goal of making our economy greener and our transportation more modern.
All European institutions have broadly supported this objective, including almost all member states and our Parliament.
In this context, it is regrettable that, since 2008, several Member States have sought to empty the new Eurovignette directive proposal of its content and to block this file.

Today, however, thanks to the tenacity of our rapporteur, and I would like to acknowledge SaÃ¯d El Kadrawi here, and to the tenacity of the shadow rapporteurs in their negotiations with the Council, we finally have a compromise before us.

Admittedly, this text is much less ambitious than the initial proposal, but it will, for the first time, enable the implementation of the polluter pays principle and the internalization of external transport costs such as noise and CO2 emissions.

In order for this euro vignette to be more than just a tax, and to effectively contribute to the improvement of transport in Europe, member states are also encouraged to reinvest the collected funds in modernizing transport modes.
The Parliament has also managed to secure concrete inventions in the area of interoperability of toll systems, as well as stronger incentives for the use of less polluting heavy-duty vehicles.

In order to remain consistent with the policy objectives our institution has set for itself, I sincerely hope that we can adopt this compromise proposed to us on second reading and thus pave the way for a more sustainable transport policy. Thank you.
Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, yes, I agree that with liberty and fraternity, there should be equality for farmers and countries returning from the East.
Yes, I agree with you.
I believe we have taken a significant step forward with this report.
It was not easy at first, and we were rather in a confrontational situation, but we reached a consensus, and that is what matters most.
This consensus makes it possible to protect the overall project, and I believe that this is the great merit of the European Parliament.
We have achieved this Paris, and it was not easy, so I thank the rapporteur and all the parliamentarians.
**Preliminary step.**
In this text, we reaffirm the necessity of equality, justice, and equity among producers and among territories, and I believe this is important.
We have stated very clearly and confirmed the preservation and development of small farms, recognizing the essential role of small farms in ensuring the quality and biodiversity of regions.
I believe it was equally fundamental.
The introduction of the concept of transitioning agricultural practices from industrial, productivity-focused agriculture to agronomic agriculture has been enshrined in text.
Now it will be necessary to implement this. It is a condition to make agriculture possible for future generations.
This is not an ideological question.
Finally, today, our concern is that there are indeed threats to the budget.
It will need to be answered clearly.

Now, what we are expecting is that we will indeed enter the second phase, which is clearly the legislative debate, because beyond the texts and grand intentions, it is in the legislative debate that we will truly see where we are headed, and that is what we are obviously expecting now.
I would still like to end by uttering a cry of anger at Germany's attitude, which has resulted in a fivefold reduction in food aid to the poorest in Europe.
It was within the budget of the CAP.
I want us to find a way to help the poorest. There are eighty million European citizens who do not eat properly.
Mr. President, while the European Parliament can boast of some significant progress in economic governance, I urge my colleagues to show humility, for we are dancing on the edge of the abyss.
Let us be fully aware of two things.
The first is that the European Parliament remained unheard during the Greek crisis.
While we are usually so quick to react to all sorts of events with resolutions, across the globe, this existential crisis seems to leave us at a loss.
I deeply regret that we were unable to send a strong, concrete, simple message to the Greeks, to the government, to the Member States, and to European citizens.
The second observation pertains to the scope of this package.
By voting for what I wish, these six amendments to the regulations, we will undoubtedly enable the eurozone to take a step forward.
towards a discipline that has been so lacking, a step, I say no more, that will demonstrate its utility in the future.
But it is enough to look at the fiery debates surrounding the qualified and reversed majority to gauge the distance we still have to cover, when it should be about automatic rules and sanctions.
The mechanism of reversed qualified majority voting continues to act as a bogeyman for some.
We must, however, remain firm on the principle.
On a strictly political level, I regret that the banks of the left continue to reject the principles of sound budgetary management against all evidence.
Yes, deficits and sustainable growth are indeed contradictory.

Yes, states must also manage their budgets prudently, like a good father managing his household, but not through public spending stimulus. It is a sweet poison in the short term, but it is never a sustainable solution.
In the coming weeks, which are crucial, it is a matter of today refounding an economic union.
This morning, after three years of work, we voted on a text that is highly significant for the advancement of consumer protection in Europe.
It rightly focuses on online shopping, which may well represent twenty-five percent of all commerce in Europe within twenty years, a truly significant figure.
These deposits will be particularly transnational.
They will enable consumers to expand their choices and also pay much less.
This is a genuine progress.
For SMEs and all artisans, this is also a very important opportunity to expand their markets.

Among the key advancements, I would like to highlight two: the extension of the cancellation period to fourteen days, and the summary of all information and the total price to be paid before finalizing the order.

Finally, I am proud, in the context of these explanations of vote, to state that not only I, but all our colleagues, voted unanimously across the political groups, because on such a topic, what we needed was not controversy, but clearly consensus.
We have obtained it.

Madam President, ladies and gentlemen of the Commission, I would like to begin by commending the efforts of our colleague Carlos Collet on this very challenging file, which required a high level of technical expertise, extensive work, and in-depth knowledge of the subject matter.
The control of our shared territory and European borders is one of the most significant challenges we must address, leveraging technological tools now more than ever to meet this task.
Indeed, in recent years, we have witnessed an unprecedented development of European databases and the exchange of personal data.
What some refer to as the digital tsunami is certainly expected to materialize in the coming years.
The SIS, the VIS, and the REDDAX are all essential tools today for ensuring the security of our European citizens.
Ensuring effective operational management of these databases is therefore a key issue for which it is our responsibility to provide an efficient solution.

This response is of course highly sensitive and Carlos Colho had to overcome numerous legal, institutional, budgetary, political, and technical obstacles, yet he managed to produce a balanced text that satisfies all interested parties.
The establishment of this network agency indeed appears to be the best solution to ensure the internal security of the Member States.
No other existing institution or agency could currently assume responsibility for the proper management of these information systems.

It will enhance the management of existing information systems, provide better synergy between its databases, and additionally, allow for the integration of instruments that will be adopted in the future.
One of the very delicate questions that arose in this file was the location of the agency: where should it be established?
Estonia and France are the only two countries that have volunteered to host it.

France already hosts the Schengen training system in Strasbourg, which it has been managing operationally and administering since 1985. Consequently, it has complete technical control over the system.
Following the conclusions of the European Council of December 2003, which gave priority to the new members in particular, Estonia also wished to host this future agency.

It seems to me that the compromise reached is excellent. A sort of distribution of emissions, if I may finish, Madam President, took place by transferring the agency's headquarters to Tallinn, where governance, strategy, and program design tasks will be carried out.
The development and operation of the systems will take place in Strasbourg.
The cost-effectiveness ratio is well-balanced, and this co-premises solution does not in any way compromise the centralized management of IT systems. Madam President,
Mr. President, the cross-cutting social clause and Article 14 of the Treaty of Lisbon bindingly guarantee social rights, and in particular the right of access to services of general interest.
It is time to prove to European citizens that social Europe is on the move.

Therefore, we must afford our social rights the full recognition they deserve within EU law, acknowledging the specific nature of SSIGs (Social and Solidarity Economy Initiatives) in relation to competition rules. These services have a strong local presence and are based on social economy actors.

Mr. De Rosssa's report provides an opportunity to affirm the simple yet powerful and profound principles of equality and universal access to these collectively organized services, which are drivers of well-being and social progress.
Madam Commissioner, you said it's time to move to the practical aspects.
Yes, it is time to move towards concrete action, so I propose, in this debate, to re-examine a European legislative instrument for social welfare services.
I therefore invite you to vote for the alternative resolution submitted to the Green group.
Mr. President, debates concerning GMOs must imperatively be based on irrefutable arguments, both from a scientific and legal standpoint.

Why have the Council's recommendations of October 2008 remained a dead letter?
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, first and foremost, I would like to thank our colleague Simon Buzitil for the outstanding work he has achieved.
These reflections have enriched the initial proposal, and we can only congratulate him for it.
This report outlines an agency with greatly enhanced capabilities, better aligned with the missions assigned to it.
Recent events have demonstrated the need for closer cooperation between the European Union, the Member States, and the support of a strong agency.
Frontex is finally being given the resources to fulfill its mandates.
By being able to acquire or rent its own equipment and avail of the services of its own border guards, it becomes more independent and highly efficient.
New tasks are also assigned to it, such as organizing voluntary returns and processing personal data, so that we can combat cross-border crime while protecting fundamental rights.

This extension of Frontex's area of expertise and border responsibilities empowers us to address and consider migration issues through a comprehensive approach, rather than being limited to mere mechanical border management.
I approve of the possibility of sharing personal data with other European agencies, including Europol.
Finally, the human dimension has fully asserted itself in this report.
A strong recognition of human rights is guaranteed by the proposal to establish an Advisory Council within the agency.

I can only welcome this comprehensive proposal, which represents a step forward towards a healthy and responsible management of our external borders, in a context where migratory pressures are particularly intense and ongoing. Thank you.

Mr. President, I would like to thank rapporteur Mr. Meyer and my colleagues for their sometimes critical remarks. This 2010 activity report is, after all, an excellent opportunity to discuss the Petitions Committee, as it remains largely unknown.
Yet, it is the Commission that has a direct, sometimes physical, link to the citizen who can attend our debates in person.
She has undeniable legitimacy in Parliament and a vast wealth of expertise due to her direct connection with citizens.
Indeed, any petitioner may go to the Parliament and defend their rights before the Committee on Petitions.
One can also commend the serenity of the debates, despite the painful cases often addressed.
This Commission represents Europe as it should be: attentive to its citizens' problems and united in finding solutions to protect them.
Unfortunately, the means of intervention and influence remain limited, particularly regarding the environmental risk of projects that are sometimes nearly completed.
But I also see it when it comes to defending specific cases such as family rights or children's rights in the event of a divorce.
We will be conducting a mission on this very subject in November.
I also regret that national authorities do not always expedite the provision of all necessary information to us.
I would like to thank the European Commission for its research and verification work, even if sometimes it could go further in the pursuit of truth.
I must also acknowledge the constructive work we are doing with the European Ombudsman.
I finally appeal to the citizens, continue to petition us as your directly elected representatives.
Our role will always be to safeguard your interests in strict compliance with European law.
Madam President, Commissioner, I welcome this resolution on the abolition of abortion, as it is our responsibility to underscore its utmost urgency.
Firstly, we observe that what was a priority yesterday remains so today, even more pressingly.

the absence of definitions and reliable statistical indicators on homelessness cannot prevent us from noting the alarming increase in the number of people living below the poverty line, which according to Eurostat, rose from sixty-nine million in 2009 to an estimated eighty-four million in 2011.
Dear colleagues, three years ago, our Parliament, concerned with eradicating poverty, called on Member States to end the problem of STIs by 2015.
Today, we have drawn a little closer to our goal.
Did the year 2010, dedicated to the fight against poverty, truly allow member states to concretely address the significant precariousness whose urgency has become permanent?
I truly allow myself to doubt it, and I deeply regret it.

To conclude, I would like to emphasize the need to develop a comprehensive, multisectoral strategy on homelessness, because, of course, there is misery and lack of housing, certainly, but there are also family problems, health issues, various addictions, or personal vulnerabilities.
A comprehensive, effective, and ambitious yet tailored approach is required, one that takes into account the individuals, the heterogeneous nature of their paths, and the disruptions in their lives.
This is a fundamental right, at the very least, from which a significant number of highly precarious individuals are excluded.
Madam President, as everyone has stated in recent years, the European Union has been struck by unprecedented catastrophe, and the cities mentioned here would take up all the debate time.
I will still cite the AZEF explosion, the tenth anniversary of which we commemorated less than a week ago in Toulouse.
A strengthened reaction at the European level, as proposed in Mrs. Gardini's report, represents a real opportunity to demonstrate solidarity among our populations.

For several years now, the Union has been attempting to make this pooling of our efforts operational, and it is now time to act together and no longer wait for a new catastrophe to strike our territories before learning from it.
Today, it is a matter of making our physical, human, and financial resources available to all, in order to prevent new tragedies from occurring.
Madam Commissioner, earlier you said that we need to anticipate risks.

It is truly regrettable that, in this context, the European Commission is considering withdrawing funding for the GMS satellite observation program, which is recognized by all as an essential tool for disaster prevention and response coordination.
I urgently call on the Commission to reconsider this position and to support these flagship programmes, which undoubtedly add value to Europe.
I would like to thank Mrs. Gardini for her excellent report.
I hope we will adopt it. It will thus open the way to European solidarity in the service of the citizen. Thank you.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Minister, the number of poor and unemployed people continues to rise within the European Union.
over forty-three million Europeans are at risk of food poverty.
The hour is grave.
Today, six Member States wish to end food aid programs without any replacement solutions: Germany, Sweden, Denmark, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, and the Czech Republic.
Indeed, there is a decision by the Court of Justice, and we must respect it.
However, Commissioner, the Parliament addressed you last July at the initiative of our Green group, and you made relevant proposals to safeguard the program.
The Greens are ready to work with you on long-term solutions, but given that millions of people depend on this system, we cannot allow the food aid budget to be cut by four-fifths.
The emergency is real.
If nothing is done, by the end of the year, more than 300 million euros will be missing for food aid, and nothing guarantees that national governments will be able to step in to fill this gap.
This is thus a real question of solidarity among peoples.
Let us not allow an irresponsible minority government to deprive millions of Europeans of food aid, because above all, it is a matter of survival.
The fight against poverty and malnutrition also requires a reform of the CAP.
We must fundamentally change our production methods to bring food production closer to the people, especially the poorest among us, who also have the right to a healthy and balanced diet.
Only a truly sustainable approach will ensure that fewer Europeans will need food aid.
The Council must come to its senses and allow those in need to avail themselves of this vital aid.
I am addressing in particular the future Danish government, which will have the responsibility of ensuring the presidency of the European Union as of January.
Return to reason. Must we wait for the kind of upheavals that marked the end of the European Union in Europe to realize the urgent need to change our approach?

When it comes to saving banks, the Council has found solutions, but when it comes to saving food banks, suddenly there is no one left. Parliament issued a strong statement last time: human beings are more important than finance.
finance. It is high time to reaffirm this.
In any case, we will remain very vigilant and will not fail to renew our constructive appeal.
Six member states hold the fate of eighteen million needy Europeans in their hands.
Six Member States that claim to be doing no more and no less than adhering to the letter of the law.
Legalism is one thing, humanism and political choices are another.
How can we not express our anger towards those who remain deaf to the alarm cries raised by the associations that aid the most vulnerable?

And we, European Parliament members, representatives of all citizens, do we want an Europe where national selfishness sets the policies, paying little regard to the citizens of states in budgetary distress?
There is no question of renationalizing this aid.
No, let us maintain this program, let us give it a stronger legal basis, but let us not abandon those who, right now, in 2012, are counting on this support during a particularly difficult crisis.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I will not dwell on the cynicism with which the ArcelorMittal group announced the closure of some of its facilities in Europe, and in particular in LiÃ¨ge, Belgium, ultimately resulting in hundreds of direct job losses and jeopardizing several thousand indirect jobs.

Russia and Brazil, the shrinking automotive market, and finally, the competitiveness gap, for instance, that of the LiÃ¨ge site compared to the top-performing factories in Northern Europe.

He paid zero euros in taxes, which corresponds to a tax rate of zero.
This is particularly shocking.
Group management is primarily financial, with a stop-and-go policy practiced across multiple sites.
The closure of sites is nothing more, in the minds of their leaders, than an economic adjustment variable where human concerns are of little importance.
This is no longer acceptable.
You spoke, Commissioner, of the rules.
Shouldn't the Commission now develop a binding social responsibility code for multinational corporations?

For six years now, our Parliament has adopted a report concerning offshoring, the corporate code of conduct, subsidy repayment, and mandatory consultation between businesses, trade unions, and public authorities.

What actions does the Commission intend to take in this regard, and within what timeframe?

a strong Europe to cope with relocations and restructuring and ensure full consideration of another capital, human capital.

Madam President, dear colleagues, the wave of layoffs hitting workers across Europe must lead us to reflect on the role we, as policymakers, have to play in the face of multinational corporations acting with impunity.

without any social ethics, carrying out stock market layoffs and offshoring to reduce costs, increase shareholder profits, and please rating agencies at the expense of social and environmental standards.

In its resolution of the twentieth of September last on the future of the Globalization Adjustment Fund, Parliament clearly expressed its will to support above all employees affected by the negative effects of restructurings.
But we also asked the Commission to ensure coherence between GEF interventions and the European Union's industrial policy, particularly through the use of structural funds.

We also insisted that the future EIB regulation include improvements to ensure that the Bank does not produce the same random moral effects on multinational corporations, as it does today with companies like ArcelorMittal and Nokia.
Commissioner, we can no longer continue to look at the issue of structural funds and the Globalization Adjustment Fund separately without...
It is important to consider the restructuring strategies of companies that benefit from them without examining the cost-benefit ratio of such policies, I reiterate.
Mr. President, the European Ombudsman diligently conducts inquiries into complaints lodged against the institutions and bodies of the European Union.

This instrument is necessary to facilitate free movement, for our businesses and citizens alike, but it also serves as a powerful guarantee, especially against the critics of the Union, who all too often claim that the European Union is merely a bureaucratic machine devoid of control.
This is clearly a nonsensical situation. Europe is engaging in genuine self-reflection, thanks in large part to the work of European mediators.
But let me relay a finding that I deeply regret, one in which the Commission is under heavy criticism.
Firstly, there are the figures sixty-five and the actual figure, not twelve, relating to the open inquiries conducted by the ombudsman concerning the European Commission.

There are also stakeholders. Many businesses come to us to express their frustration with a European Commission that remains unresponsive to their requests, particularly regarding access to documents. The same applies to the issue of transparency in decision-making.
Few people find their way there.
And finally, from personal experience, I must admit that I have sometimes been shocked by the reactions of certain services of the European Commission present in the Committee on Petitions.
As you know, the European Commission provides us with its position on petitions, a position that we always take into account and which is necessary.

But it occasionally happens that we see representatives of the European Commission who refuse to answer questions from an MEP or who take refuge in bureaucratic language almost as well as politicians do when faced with citizens advocating their cause.

I therefore wanted to remind you that Europe must have a human face, that behind the administrative issues addressed and resolved by the ombudsman, there are Europeans who are grateful to be heard but are disappointed by

citizen behavior, which is then negatively influenced by their confrontation with institutions, potentially creating a sense of revolt, misunderstanding, and perhaps even Euroscepticism in the long term.
I sincerely hope that these criticisms and those of the mediator against institutions in general are heeded. Thank you.
Madam President, professional mobility and growth, professional mobility and the competitiveness of our European Union, these are indeed the terms in which today's subject is framed.
We, in the EPP group, have voiced our support for the report by our colleague Mrs Mclarkin, to the drafting of which we have greatly contributed, and we obviously support the...

key recommendations of this report are for increased professional mobility, greater simplification and efficiency in the procedures for recognizing professional qualifications, while ensuring patient safety and consumer protection.

Certainly, the crisis is economic and financial, but above all, for our fellow citizens, it is a social crisis.
Reducing the number of people living in precarious situations by twenty million by 2020 requires strong measures involving different levels of public authority.

We must, now more than ever, uphold the commitments made by the European Union in 2010, during the European Year for Combating Poverty and Social Exclusion, and at the launch of the European Platform against Poverty and Social Exclusion, in order to establish a European framework for social and territorial cohesion.

We must secure and optimize European funds, including the aid program for the most deprived, which is currently being maintained, improve social protection, and support local or national initiatives that develop services for the care of children, the elderly, and dependent persons.
Poverty is a scourge to be fought at the horizontal level, and it is now time to act to enable the most disadvantaged to escape their precariousness.

As policymakers, at the European, national, and local levels, we must take the necessary measures to ensure them, without discrimination, access to housing, healthcare, justice, education, and a first job with a minimum income that can be indexed according to each member state's poverty threshold.
Investing in the promotion of innovation and social experimentation, as well as in poverty reduction, will enable us to implement a sustainable, smart, and inclusive growth strategy.
The Europe we wish for and need today is a Europe of solidarity.

Indeed, combating illegal fishing requires comprehensive solutions and enforcement by all states, including developing nations.
However, it is necessary that the technical and financial capacities of states are also taken into account in the actions to be undertaken.
Indeed, the same constraints cannot be imposed without accompanying measures on either developed or developing countries.
Small island states, for instance, have very limited capacities.
Therefore, we must support them in their efforts to combat illegal fishing.
That is why the Union must increase the financial envelope for the fisheries sector when it concludes agreements in this field in developing countries.

Moreover, it is crucial that measures to combat illegal fishing be implemented, as this practice undermines the development of countries by reducing the financial resources they could derive from fishing economic activity.
Now, these resources are essential for developing countries to implement social, economic, and educational policies.

Finally, it is important that the European Union, when implementing these measures to combat illegal fishing in developing countries, promote the involvement of civil society and businesses alongside the recipient states of the aid.
A holistic and necessary approach is required to stem the scourge of illegal fishing. Thank you.

We finally come to the vote on this report, which is extremely important, as it allows us to bring the difficulties and concerns of our citizens to the attention of the Commission and the Council in this hemicycle.

Petitions concerning the environment are predominant, and waste is a significant concern among our fellow citizens.
This topic must address a societal issue.

We are only now realizing that what we do not consume, we throw away.
