A market of seventy-five billion euros inevitably attracts covetousness.
States must send a strong signal.
There must be increased penalties for companies that abuse public contracts for personal gain.
This report serves as a warning signal to the states, but the European Commission must also play its part and ensure the proper implementation of the waste directives.
This file must be made visible, but also credible.
If no one plays along, we will continue to waste time and money on verification and counter-verification processes that could drag on for years.
Let us heed the petitioners' message and halt this mess more swiftly.

Madam Commissioner, the data protection standards of third countries still differ significantly from European standards.
It is, however, our duty to ensure that our prevailing European minimal standards of protection are respected and guaranteed to European citizens.
It is fundamental that personal data is processed lawfully and collected for specified and legitimate purposes.

European citizens must be able to enjoy a guaranteed right of access and rectification to their personal data, as well as the right to initiate legal proceedings in the event of a violation of their rights.
Action is needed to allow European and international standards to coexist and resolve a legal conflict that could be detrimental to European citizens.
European legislation alone is not sufficient.
It must be intelligently articulated and coexist with international standards, as we can shirk our duties and commitments to European citizens.
This situation resonates with other debates within this chamber.
It reminds us of the relevance of projects such as the establishment of a European program for monitoring the financing of terrorism.
Such a system would provide us with a tool that has proven its effectiveness in the United States, while fully respecting domestic law and thus the protection of personal data of European citizens.
European institutions must continue their commitment in this regard and fully uphold their protection standards. Thank you.

I believe that taxation is an interesting tool for changing behaviors.

I believe that energy consumption should be aligned with an indicative price signal for consumers. Moreover, I maintain that, to prevent any distortions in the internal market, we must strive to harmonize our tax practices.
The principle of proportionality among the different levels of taxation on energy products seems to me to be a necessity.
In the case at hand, for instance, this would put an end to the diesel tourism we are currently witnessing, which is not an acceptable phenomenon.
I therefore share the philosophy of the Commission's proposal for a revised directive.

However, if we are to achieve our goals in terms of reducing CO2 emissions or improving energy efficiency, our collective decisions must not penalize citizens or sectors that are particularly vulnerable to these changes.

price volatility in world markets, and I think of the agricultural sector, for example. The proposed directive will have an impact, certainly differentiated according to the tax level of each Member State, but an impact nonetheless on the price of diesel.

Earlier here, we had a debate on the wave of layoffs in Europe due to the economic crisis, particularly at Arcelor, a multinational present in nine European Union member states. The company is restructuring its production facilities in Europe in response to a decline in steel demand.
With the shutdown of two blast furnaces in Belgium and Luxembourg, and the idling of one blast furnace in France, it is estimated that nearly 6 direct jobs will be at risk for the year 2012.

Beyond unacceptable practices such as stoppengo, a practice that should be better regulated, it is the broader question of European steelmaking and adaptation to change that requires extremely urgent responses.

Six months ago, the Commission announced to us the necessity of conducting a new consultation exercise, in light of the economic crisis, for the responsible management of restructuring with social partners and public authorities.
My question is straightforward: six months later, where do we stand?

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, first of all, I would like to refute the unfounded claims of the circulation in France of 500 to one million fake biometric passports that are said to be in circulation in our country.
France takes the risks of identity fraud extremely seriously.
It does not take infractions in this matter lightly.
At the initiative of its government, identity usurpation is an offense punishable by one year in prison and a fine of 15 euros.
The conditions for issuing identity documents have been simplified, enabling prefectures to allocate additional resources to combat this fraud.
Thus, in each prefecture, a fraud liaison officer is appointed.
Furthermore, the provisions for securing and issuing identity documents have been strengthened.
For example, the civil status data provided can be verified between administrative services, insofar as possible, in a dematerialized manner in order to limit the risks of falsification.
Some birth certificates are also issued on secure paper.
The same rigor applies to the supporting documents for proof of residence.
The Ministry of the Interior has embarked on a course of enhancing the security of proof of residence documents through the inclusion of a barcode.

The classic treatment of a title request includes authorized consultation of relevant files, comparison of all documents produced in previous title requests, and the potential authentication of supporting documents.

The secure issuance of titles is further guaranteed by the double appearance of the applicant 1 at the time of filing the application and subsequently at the time of collecting the title, as well as the taking of two fingerprints.
And let's not forget the enhanced checks for renewing lost and stolen documents for comparative purposes with the data held by the prefectures. I conclude.

Furthermore, France reports to international cooperation bodies, notably Interpol. In conclusion, Mr. President, I have nearly completed the process of reporting lost or stolen passports to prevent their fraudulent use.
My dear colleagues, France, along with the entire network of the European Union, is committed.

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, firstly, it is evident that our fellow citizens are increasingly seeking to find and consume locally produced and seasonal food for health and quality reasons, among others.
We must find ways to enable farmers to respond effectively and swiftly to this growing demand.

We must support the development of local infrastructures for producers, such as maintaining local slaughterhouses which, while ensuring strict health controls, enable the growth of local short-circuit supply chains and strengthen direct sales.
Support for local agriculture and direct sales should help producers market their products and raise awareness among consumers.
Strengthening these direct relationships will enable farmers to retain a larger portion of the added value generated on their farms.

It is necessary to promote and facilitate direct sales on the farm and to support collective actions by farmers who wish to open collective sales points, thereby offering local consumers a wider range of products.

The European Commission should facilitate the emergence, sustainability, and development of direct consumer delivery sales systems, such as the AMAPs (Association for the Maintenance of Peasant Agriculture) in France, which enable nearly 3 farmers to supply sixty families.
Finally, member states must be able to add other criteria, particularly concerning farm size, production volume, or the traditional nature of the product, to define local agriculture.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Rapporteur, thank you for the work we have accomplished together.
The European Union needs a manifesto, a shared political vision for the major environmental challenges facing us by 2020 and beyond.
This is why it is so important to launch a seventh environmental action program, by synergizing existing financial frameworks and mobilizing new funding resources.
This program must ensure consistency and alignment between the European Union's environmental strategies and sectoral policies, whether in agriculture,
fishing, research and innovation, health, transportation, regional development, territorial planning, and urban policies, of course.
Despite the economic crisis that is affecting the European Union, we must not give in to a short-term vision and abandon all ambition in the environmental and climate realm.
Inaction would be fatal.
The stakes are too high, especially regarding the efficient use of our resources and the enhancement of natural capital.
We must therefore resolutely invest in sustainable economy and ecinnovation, a source of growth, competitiveness, and employment.
It is our responsibility to promote ecodesign, recycling, but also the environmental labeling of products in order to avoid waste and poor consumer choices.
We cannot overlook this environmental pedagogy, essential for European citizens.
The environmental action program is a political policy instrument, but it is also a communication tool.

It must provide the necessary readability and predictability for national and local administrations, citizens, but also entrepreneurs and investors regarding the European Union's environmental choices.
European regulation must not become a punishment or a straitjacket.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, in the face of the profound changes our world is undergoing today, the Union must reform its generalized preference system.
Like any compromise, this one does not deviate from the rule.
While it is satisfactory from a strictly commercial perspective, it is far from being perfect. We must bear in mind that this regulation is intended for developing countries.
In developing its new paradigm of differentiation, the Commission states its intention to refocus its action in support of the poorest countries.
This does not seem at all tenable at first glance.
To achieve this, the Commission has nonetheless developed a strictly accounting-based vision, relying solely on the criterion of GDP per capita.

Commissioner, the issue of public consultations being available in various languages was unfortunately not a new concern.

This is, in my view, a crucial issue, which is why I have not only submitted several written questions to the European Commission since 2008, but I have also personally questioned Mr Barroso in writing.

Indeed, the Commission must adhere to the principle of equal access to information for all European citizens, as recalled by the Court of First Instance of the European Communities in its judgment of November 20, 2008.
I was not at all satisfied with the response from the European Commission, which stated that public consultations do not claim to provide a fully representative picture of all opinions.
According to this response, the Commission acknowledges that certain positions and views may be overrepresented at the expense of others.
This is not an answer.
I am inquiring about the criteria that would enable us to measure the overrepresentation of the European population.
If written consultations are not representative due solely to their availability in English, for instance, they fail in their purpose of consulting European citizens.
Thus, the result provides a misleading indication and should therefore not be used by the European Commission.
If we wish to maintain secret consultations as a tool underpinning the legislative proposals of the European Commission, we must ensure they are democratic, transparent, and fair for all citizens.
Therefore, if the European Commission circulates the written document, it must take responsibility and provide the necessary resources for multilingualism and the translation of questionnaires.
In conclusion, I would like to add that multilingualism is not the only obstacle.

It would also be necessary to include in the analysis the overly short deadlines for submissions and contributions, as well as the limited resources deployed by the Commission to communicate about these consultations, which are unfortunately mostly accessible to insiders. Thank you.

Mr. President, dear colleagues, I speak on behalf of Maurice Pongard, rapporteur for the Development Committee's opinion on Mr. Gallagher's report.
It seemed important to me to recall that, when it wishes to sanction a country that practices unsustainable fishing, it must take into account its level of development.

Indeed, in the name of the principle of policy coherence for development, it is crucial, in my view, that the measures adopted regarding fisheries do not undermine the development plans and strategies implemented by the European Union in these countries.
Mr Gallagher's draft report takes up this important idea for our Development Committee by stipulating that measures must not be unjustified or even discriminatory.

I therefore invite the European Commission, when adopting such measures, to respect the principle of policy coherence with development objectives, and for the level of development and vulnerability of countries to be duly taken into account. Thank you.
The third reform of the common fisheries policy must not once again be carried out against the interests of fishermen.

No, not all fishermen are these sea plunderers, solely responsible for the poor health and depletion of stocks, as environmental organizations and the European Commission claim, by lumping together all categories of fishing.

It is understood that fish stocks must be preserved, but we must also enable our fishing sailors to make a living from their activities and protect the economic fabric, dynamism, and cultural identity of our coastal regions.
Now, the main measures of the European executive once again aim to reduce the number of fishermen to achieve the mythical maximum sustainable yield.
I remind you that the French fleet has decreased by more than fifty since nineteen eighty.

The Commission proposes, in particular, the introduction of individual transferable quotas, which would ensure the industrialization and concentration of the sector, as well as a complete ban on discards, which professionals deem unrealistic.
This reform project may suit the industrial fleet, but as it stands, it would mean the programmed death of what remains of local and artisanal fishing.

We all know here that the European Union provides more than half of the world's total official development assistance, and yet, as we approach the 2015 deadline for the MDGs, even though some targets seem
Having achieved this, we must now ask ourselves how to improve our aid, to make it more consistent with our trade policy, our agricultural policy, and our foreign policy.
The future of European development policy must be based on specific, measurable commitments, with a short- and medium-term timeline.

The economic crisis, climate change, the rising power of emerging countries, and land grabbing compel us to define new priorities to ensure food security, access to energy resources, and access to healthcare.

Indeed, a European consensus exists, but we need to rethink European and international institutional systems regarding environmental and social matters, drawing inspiration from organizations that effectively make decisions, such as the WTO, for instance.
Finally, and above all, we must explain to our fellow citizens that the development of third countries is not merely a matter of charity and solidarity, but also a source of development for us.
One need only look at the markets opening up for Europeans in emerging countries such as China, Brazil, and India.
2015 will also be an opportunity to better account for the geostrategic shifts of recent years, as the emerging countries of today were, until recently, still developing nations.
Henceforth, as indispensable economic powers, these countries must also contribute to international aid.
The European Union must be the promoter of responsible development aid at both the European and international levels.

The year 2015 will be more than a deadline; it will be a unique opportunity to rethink development aid, not as mere financial assistance, but as support for responsible development projects, both socially and environmentally.

I therefore join my colleagues from other groups, as well as those from the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions, in calling for 2015 to be designated the European Year of Development, and above all, of responsible development.
Mr. President, the agenda for change proposed by the Commission, in my view, raises many questions, the primary one being the concrete implementation of the principle of differentiation.

The Commission intends that, starting in 2014, the selection of countries in which the European Union will invest its development aid will be based on the mechanical application of the sole criterion of per capita wealth.
As Mrs Ashton reminded us, these issues are not merely accounting matters, but warrant a genuine political debate on defining our priorities in international cooperation.
Moreover, this differentiated approach, in my view, is not in keeping with the spirit of the Cotonou Agreement.

I am convinced that ACP countries that have achieved positive economic performance should be encouraged in their transition towards more sustainable growth. Mr. President, as a member of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, I took a keen interest in the report by my colleague Regina Bastos concerning the twenty main concerns of citizens and businesses.
We discussed this report, incidentally in connection with our debate on the twenty years of the internal market.
It has already been twenty years since the free movement of goods, people, services, and capital was supposed to be fully realized within our living space, our area of exchange, our internal market.

I was particularly interested in the fact that, at the forefront, the concerns expressed by our European fellow citizens cite the lack of professional qualifications, and that we truly need to be especially proactive and particularly effective.

This is what our fellow citizens rightfully expect us to achieve in the very near future: the implementation of faster, simpler, more efficient, and less costly procedures for recognizing their diplomas, skills, and professional qualifications.
This is a real challenge.

As the shadow rapporteur for the EPE group on the topic of modernizing these procedures, I am actively working with the other members of the IMCO Committee to genuinely address this major challenge of mobility.
More mobility, for more Europe, is what our fellow citizens are asking for. Thank you.
